loans.name: La Estancia ( Cuenca ) Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal La Estancia está formado por un grupo de 12 señoras quienes con su trabajo y esfuerzo luchan para brindarles a sus familias un mejor futuro, viven en la comunidad de La Estancia y el Cabo, estas comunidades pertenecientes al cantón Paute que se caracteriza por ser la mayor productora de flores, cuentan con la hidroeléctrica mas grande del país y su gente en su mayor parte viven del la agricultura y ganadería.
 
La Señora Emma Yolanda F. vive en la comunidad del Cabo, tiene 35 años, es casada y tiene 4 hijos de 19, 17, 14 y 12 años de edad, todos estudian en el colegio, su esposo quien trabaja arduamente labora en el arte de la construcción como albañil, gracias al esfuerzo y trabajo en conjunto tienen su casa propia. 
Nuestra socia se dedica a los quehaceres de su casa y  aprovecha para criar cuyes, a los cuales los vende en el mercado de su cantón y también en su casa. Es su primer crédito, ha ingresado a la banca comunal gracias a una amiga que es socia, el dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de chanchos. Su meta es construir un galpón más grande para sus cuyes y también para criar gallinas.

La Señora María Asunción C. vive en la comunidad del Cabo, es su primer crédito y fue invitada por una amiga de su comunidad, se dedica a la cría de animales como: pollos, cuyes, vacas y chanchos actividad que la realiza hace 3 años, los pollos los vende pelados o vivos según la preferencia del cliente, también tiene clientes fijos que le compran la leche de sus vacas.
Nuestra socia tienen 55 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos de 41 y 32 años de edad, son  casados y viven de manera independiente, su esposo trabaja en el cría de pollos y con el trabajo de los dos han logrado construir su casa propia. Su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cuyes y en el alimento de los mismos. Su meta es seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
The “El Estancia” communal bank is made up of 12 women who work hard to provide a better future for their families. They live in the “Estancia” and “Cabo” communities within the Paute hamlet. This area is known for being the largest producer of flowers and for having the largest hydroelectric plant in the country. Most of its inhabitants raise crops and livestock. Mrs. Emma Yolanda F. lives in Cabo and is 35 years old. She is married and has four children, ages 19, 17, 14, and 12. All attend school. Her husband works diligently in construction as a mason. They have their own home, thanks to their effort and hard work. [Emma] is a homemaker who takes advantage of the time to raise Guinea pigs, which she sells out of her home and at the market in her hamlet. This will be her first loan. She became part of her communal bank, thanks to a friend who is also a member. She will use the money from this loan to buy hogs. Her goal is to build a larger pen for her Guinea pigs and also to raise chickens. Mrs. María Asunción C. also lives in Cabo and this will be her first loan as well. She was invited into the group by a friend of hers from the community. She raises livestock, such as chickens, Guinea pigs, cattle, and hogs and has been doing this for three years. She sells the chickens either alive or processed, according to each customer’s preference. She also has steady customers who buy milk from her cows. [María] is 55 years old, married, and has two children, ages 41 and 32. They are married and on their own. Her husband raises chickens and they have managed to build their house thanks to their hard work. She will use the money from this loan to buy Guinea pigs and feed. Her goal is to continue to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Livestock and feed

loans.name: Gladys Narcisa

texts.es:
Gladys Narcisa O. F. tiene 33 años.  Es casada y vive en el cantón de Chillanes en la provincia de Bolívar. Tiene 5 hijos de 14 a 4 anos. 

Gladys es un socio de la ventanilla rural El Placer, que está ubicada a tres horas de Chillanes. Son 19 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican al cultivo de maíz y cacao. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Gladys se dedica a trabajar en una cacaotera. 

Solicita el préstamo para sembrar maíz y comprar abonos y semillas y para sembrar independemente eventualmente. Su sueño es comprar terreno, apoyar a sus hijos y darles a sus estudios. 

No tiene tiempo libre.
texts.en:
Gladys Narcisa O. F. is 33 years old. She is married and lives in the canton of Chillanes, in Bolívar province. She has 5 children, ranging from 4 to 14 years old. Gladys is a member of the rural solidarity group El Placer, located three hours from Chillanes. It has a total of 19 members, most of whom are involved in growing corn and cacao [cocoa]. This is their first loan through the San José Cooperative. Gladys works on a cacao plantation. She is requesting the loan to plant corn and buy fertilizer and seeds, so that she can eventually become an independent producer. Her dream is to buy land, support her children and provide them with a university education. She has no free time.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Planting corn

loans.name: Xiomara Del Socorro

texts.es:
Xiomara del Socorro M. Martínez tiene 46 años y vive  con su cónyuge e hijo de 19 años, en el popular barrio 7 de Abril al suroccidende de la ciudad de Barranquilla, donde se dedica a vender queso y  pan.  
Xiomara M. nació en Zambrano una población del departamento de Bolívar, desde que tenia 13 años se residenció en Barranquilla, allí estudió hasta décimo grado y continuó haciendo un curso de técnica en Belleza, a sus 21 años contrajo matrimonio  y con el conocimiento de esta actividad,  empezó a generar mayores ingresos al hogar, pero desde hace 5 años se dedicó a la comercialización de panes, que produce su esposo en una panadería donde es empleado y también vende de queso  que  compra en Zambrano y lo trae para venderlo en Barranquilla.  Este es su quinto crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y lo invertirá en comprar queso por mayor cantidad y productos de panadería para diversificar su oferta, con los créditos recibidos ha logrado incrementar sus ingresos y ha podido hacer arreglos locativos a su vivienda, así mismo aporta mucho mas a su hogar y eso es bueno para que entre todos logren ser exitosos.
Xiomara sueña con tener una casa propia y trabaja todos los días con esta propuesta en su mente por eso en cada persona ve un cliente y siempre está presta a ofrecerle sus productos.
texts.en:
Xiomara del Socorro M. Martínez is 46 years old and lives with her husband and 19 year old son in the trendy April 7th neighborhood in southwestern Barranquilla. She sells cheese and bread.

Xiomara M. was born in Zambrano, a town in the Department of Bolívar. She moved to Barranquilla when she was 13. There she studied through the tenth grade and continued taking technical courses in cosmetology. At 21 she got married and began her existing business in order to generate more household income. Five years ago she focused on selling breads that her husband produces at the bakery where he is employed. She also buys cheese in Zambrano and brings it with her to sell in Barranquilla.

This is her fifth loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. She will invest in the purchase of cheese in large quantities and baked goods so that she can diversify her offering. With the loans she has already received, Xiomara has been able to increase her earnings and make repairs to her home. In addition, she has been able to contribute more to the household which helps everyone in her family become successful.

Xiomara dreams of having a house of her own and works every day with that goal in mind. She views each person as a potential customer and is always ready to offer her products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cheese & baked goods to sell

loans.name: Mabel Aura

texts.es:
Mabel Aura Bozón es una mujer muy trabajadora y madre de una  solo hija, que en la actualidad cuenta con 49 años; Mabel vende mercancía en general especialmente productos de belleza y cosméticos y también  tiene en su pequeña sala,  el negocio de transcripciones que está a cargo de su hija. Comenzó su negocio con $500.000 COP, dinero  que le prestó su hermana  y con el cual a través de su trabajo ha logrado reproducir y esto ha sido muy importante porque  teniendo un negocio fue como la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo le ha prestado 2 veces para ayudarla a reproducir su capital de trabajo; con su credikiva Mabel comprará una nueva línea de perfumería y cosméticos que tiene encargados entre sus clientes que son trabajadores, vecinos, familiares y referidos que le suministran sus buenos clientes.
Ella manifiesta que  con sus créditos a esta organización, sus inventarios han aumentado, logrando una mayor clientela, así también  el incremento significativo de   sus ventas. Su sueño ahora es ubicarse en un local de un centro comercial, donde pueda mostrar su mercancía aplicando todo su conocimiento en el arte de exhibir los productos y donde observe gran afluencia de publico que puedan ser sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mabel Aura Bozón is a very hard-working woman and the mother of just one daughter. She is currently 49 years old. Mabel sells general merchandise, especially beauty products and cosmetics, and she also has a small office with a transcription business operated by her daughter. She began her business with 500,000 COP, which her sister lent to her, and which through her hard work she was able to earn back. This has been very important for her, since because she has a business, the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation has granted her 2 loans, helping her to expand her working capital. With her loan from Kiva, Mabel will buy a new line of perfumes and cosmetics which her customers have ordered. Her customers include local workers, neighbors and family members, as well as people referred to her by her best clients. Mabel says that with her loans from this organization, her inventory has expanded and she has gained more customers along with a significant increase in sales. Her dream now is to move her business to a store in a shopping center, where she can display her merchandise more effectively, applying all of her knowledge of the art of exhibiting her products, and where she can reach a much more affluent group of potential customers.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a new line of perfumes and cosmetics which her customers have ordered

loans.name: Sros' Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of nine people who live in Ampil Toek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sros C., 48, is the village bank president.  She was selected for this role by the other members, who will use their portions of the loan to support their different businesses. 

Mrs. Sros C. and her husband, Mr. Leng Lors, are fishermen who own a fishing boat. They have two children; one is employed in a hotel and the other one, age 4, is not yet in school. This couple have a problem because their fishing boat has been leaking. Mrs. Sros C. decided to ask for a loan to fix up her fishing boat.

loans.use: To fix her fishing boat

loans.name: Adriano

texts.en:
Adriano D. is from the town of Banga. He is 50 years old. Adriano is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Adriano owns & operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale. Adriano has been engaged in his business for over 20 years.

Adriano joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adriano has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Adriano is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Adriano from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Deolinda

texts.en:
Deolinda N. is from the town of Banga. She is 57 years old. Deolinda is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Deolinda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also manages a sari-sari store located at their house. She dreams of a bigger store and a productive rice farm.

Deolinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Deolinda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Deolinda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure, and additional store inventory. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Deolinda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure, and additional store inventory.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha C. is from the town of Banga. She is 55 years old. Editha is widowed and has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Editha owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises hogs for sale. She hopes to acquire more piglets that she can raise.

Editha joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Editha has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Editha is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure, and livestock feed. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Editha from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure, and livestock feed.

loans.name: Min Maiya

texts.en:
"This is 21 year old Min Maiya L..  She is married and has no children. In 2010, she established her grocery business. Working 6 days a week and 9 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW, and used her most recent loan to purchase grocery goods. In the future, Min Maiya plans to expand her shop. She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called pasals, are an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha C. is from the town of Banga. She is 59 years old. Editha is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Editha owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Editha has been farming for fifteen years already. She recently started raising hogs to have an extra source of income. She says she wants to buy more piglets to add to her livestock.

Editha joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Editha has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Editha is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizers and also feed for the pigs. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Editha from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds and fertilizers, and also feed for the pigs.

loans.name: Mrs. Phalla Oem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of twenty people who live in Svay Pang Ankrang village in Kandal province. Mrs. Phalla O., 35, is the village bank president.  She was selected for this role by the other members, who will use their portions of the loan to support their different businesses. 

Mrs. Phalla O. and her husband, Mr. Ra Tith, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate leeks and bananas. The couple have four children; three are farmers and the other is a fruit seller in the local market.  They work very hard to support their family. They will use the requested loan from AMK to buy fertilizer for their farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for their farm

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seven people who live in Bat Lvea village in Kandal province. Mr. Chea H., age 38, is the village bank president.  He was selected for this role by the other members, who will use their portions of the loan for various purposes. 

Mr. Chea H. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultitvates rice for a living. He is also the village chief and a wedding chef while his wife, Mrs. Tho Loem, is a dessert seller and also supports her husband on the farm. The couple have four children; three are students in the local school while the youngest, age 5, does not attend school yet.  With their various occupations, Mr. Chea H. and his wife are able to earn a small income to support their family. He is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, which he will use on his farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Mohan Maiya

texts.en:
This is 40 year old Mohan Maiya R.. She is married and has 2 children aged 14 and 7. In 2009, she established her grocery business. Working 6 days a week and 9 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 7 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy grocery goods. In the future, Mohan Maiya plans to expand her shop.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called pasals, are an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods.

loans.name: Chanthou's Group

texts.en:
This village loan is made up of six members who live in Preak Snay village, Kandal province. Mrs. Phal C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Each member of this group will use his or her portion of the loan to support a different business.
Mrs. Phal C. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, she is also a fish seller in the local market. She will use her loan from Kiva partner, AMK, to buy more fish to sell. From both her businesses, Mrs. Phal C. is able to earn a small income to support her family. Mrs. Phal C. is a widow with two children, who are both seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Jonh

texts.en: Mr. Jonh P. is a villager from Prey Sandaek village, Takeo province. He was born in 1960 and is the father of a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. Jonh and his wife, Mrs. Srey Mom Tun, are farmers who own a plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. Jonh is also a musician. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. Therefore, Mr. Jonh P. is asking for a loan to buy speakers to rent out for parties.

loans.use: To buy speakers to rent out for parties

loans.name: Mach's Group

texts.en:
This group loan is made up of five people who live in Chong Kaoh village, Kandal province. Mrs. Mach M. is the group leader who has been selected by the members. Each member of this group will use her portion of the loan to support a different business.
Mrs. Mach M. and her husband, Mr. Touch Tai, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate leeks and bananas. In order to support this farm, Mrs. Mach M. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. The couple is able to earn a small income from the farm to support the family. The couple has two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other of whom is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate leeks and bananas

loans.name: Si Lorn

texts.en: Mrs. Si Lorn S. is a villager from Kdei Ta Hok village, Takeo province. She was born in 1980. She and her husband, Mr. Sophorl Porng, are farmers who own a 3.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Si Lorn S. is also a Khmer cake maker. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil and is far away from an irrigation system. Therefore, to improve production, Mrs. Si Lorn S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and preside. She is a mother of two children, all of whom are too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline and preside

loans.name: Phal's Group

texts.en:
This group loan is made up of four members who live in Preak Ta Hang village, Kandal province. Mrs. Phal H., aged 50, is the group leader who has been selected by the members. Each member of this group will use her portion of the loan to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support her business.
Mrs. Phal H. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. In addition to farming, she is also a pig breeder at home. In order to support her pig breeding business, she will use her loan from Kiva partner, AMK, to buy piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Bunna Nov, is a construction worker. With their jobs, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. The couple has five children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a teacher, one works in a casino club, while the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding

loans.name: Indira

texts.en:
This is 27 year old Indira T.. She is married and has one child, aged 4.  In 2008, she established her poultry business. Working 7 days a week and 5 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy small chickens. In the future, Indira plans to expand her poultry farm. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, raising poultry for eggs and meat is a very profitable business. Kiva loans are used to purchase chicks, food, and necessary medicine to keep the chickens healthy. Once mature, the chickens are sold at small butcher shops or in the many open air markets throughout the valley.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Hoang's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five people who are located in Pouthi Reamea village, Kandal province. Mrs. Hoang C. is the group leader of the loan, having been selected by its five members. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their particular business.

Mrs. Hoang C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate peanuts for a living. Her husband, Mr. Tot San, is a vehicle-driving laborer. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family.

In order to increase her income to improve their family living, Mrs. Hoang C. will use this loan from AMK to buy a fishing machine and a fishing boat for her new business.

This couple has four children: three are seamstresses in the garment factory while the other one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy a fishing machine and a fishing boat for her new business

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Vorn M., born in 1975, is a married woman who lives in Ta Vong village, Takeo province. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

Mrs. Vorn M. is a weaver who is able to earn some money to support her family. Moreover, she is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Van Bun, is a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.

Although they both try to work a lot, they are able earn less income than needed. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. Vorn M. is applying for a loan to buy an agricultural machine to rent to other farmers.

Mrs. Vorn M. is the mother of four children, three of whom are studying in local public school, while the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To buy an agricultural machine to rent to farmers

loans.name: Lath's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lath T., age 32, is the leader of this group loan having been selected by its four members who all live in Kám Samnor Leu village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their particular business.

Mrs. Lath T. and her husband, Mr. Chhit Put, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming, Mrs. Lath T. also breeds pigs at home. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family.

For her pig breeding, Mrs. Lath T. will use the loan from AMK to buy pig feed.

This couple has four children: one is a farmer while the other three are students and also support their parents’ farming.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs

loans.name: Tsendsuren

texts.en:
Tsendsuren H. is 44 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hovd province, western Mongolia, in their own house. His two children attend a local middle school, while his wife helps with his business. Tsendsuren operates a clothing trade business, along with working as a doctor in his town's police department.

He began his clothing trading business in 2005, and he has quickly found success. He works very hard to understand his new business and has already gained much experience. He knows he must continue to work hard and improve his selling skills if he wants to improve his business. He says, "In the future, I hope to expand my business so that I can improve our family's quality of life. My wife also wishes to create her own workplace as a small sewing shop." Tsendsuren is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a variety of clothing for the upcoming academic new year.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Somony

texts.en:
In Ta Vong village, Takeo province lives Mr. Somony K. who was born in 1964. He is a policeman who earns a very low salary to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Ly Srun, is a farmer who owns a 2.5-hectare (6.25-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. His wife is shown with him in the photo.

They both try to work hard but still they are able to earn very little to support their family. So, to improve this condition, Mr. Somony K. is seeking a loan to buy a plowing machine to rent to other farmers.

Mr. Somony K. is the father of four children who are all attending the local public school. They also help their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy a plowing machine to rent to other farmers

loans.name: Simon's Group

texts.en:
Six people located in Lekh Pir village, Kandal province, make up this village loan. Mrs. Simon H., a married woman age 31, is the village bank president having been selected by its members. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their particular business.

Mrs. Simon H. and her husband, Mr. Vann Soem, are vegetable sellers in Phnom Penh market. With this business they are able to earn a small income to support their family living.

For their vegetable selling they do not have a trailer to transport their vegetables to sell in Phnom Penh. Thus, Mrs. Simon H. decided to ask for a loan to buy a Khmer trailer to transport their vegetables.

This couple has five children: one is seamstress in a garment factory, one is a vegetable seller, two are attending the local school, while a youngest one is a year old.

loans.use: To buy a Khmer trailer to transport her vegetables

loans.name: Chimgee

texts.en:
Chimgee T. is 32 years old and lives with her husband and son in Hovd province, western Mongolia. She and her family have been living in their own house for three years. Her son goes to a local kindergarten, while her husband Ganchudur helps with her business.

Chimgee and her husband began their business in 2005 and now they are planning on expanding their business by adding more computers so that they can accommodate more customers. Chimgee is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more computers for the PC game center.

loans.use: To purchase computers for her business.

loans.name: Srey Moeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Moeurn S., a 30-year-old farmer living in Si Sla village, Takeo Province, owns a 1.5 hectare plot of land upon which she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Korb Kuch, shown in the photo with her, is a motorbike taxi driver who also owns a threshing machine. Srey Moeurn's problem is that her field is currently infertile, so she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and some gasoline. She is a mother of three children who study in local public school and also help their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Sumitra

texts.en:
This is 48 year old Sumitra T.. She is married and has 3 children between the ages of 24 and 18. In 2008, she established a business raising cows. Working 7 days a week and 5 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 5 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy a young dairy cow. In the future, Sumitra plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: To buy young dairy cows.

loans.name: Lay's Group

texts.en:
This group loan is made up of four members who all live in Kok Til village in Kandal province. Mr. Lay S., aged 43, is the leader of this group having been selected by the members. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different businesses. 
Mr. Lay S. and his wife, Mrs. Savart Yoeun, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice and sweet potato. In order to support this farm, Mr. Lay S. will use his loan from Kiva partner, AMK, to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming laborers to cultivate rice and sweet potato. In addition to farming, Mr. Lay S. is also a motorbike taxi driver who is able to earn a small income to support his family. The couple has three children, two of whom are students and also traditional musicians, and the other of whom is aged five and not yet in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming laborers

loans.name: Choijamts

texts.en:
Choijamts D. is 28 years old and lives with his wife and son in Uvs province, western Mongolia, in their own ger (a traditional housing tent). His wife works a saleswoman in a food shop, while his son goes to kindergarten.

His initial business was selling bricks, which he began in 2007. Since 2009, Choijamts has been growing vegetables on 0.4 hectares of land in the yard where the family lives, with the help of his supportive brother. He works very hard to understand his new business and has already gained much experience. His vegetable growing business is quite seasonal, so he has been thinking of purchasing a car to operate a transportation business for the rest of the time. Choijamts is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a car in order to increase his business revenues.

loans.use: To purchase a car.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San T., aged 46, lives in Srae Vong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support her family. She is also a Khmer cake maker. Her husband, Mr. Ban Chay, is a construction worker and also a palm juice collector.
Mrs. San T.'s problem is that she does not have enough oxen to plow her land. To solve this problem, Mrs. San T. is seeking a loan to buy two oxen to plow her field. Through farming the couple support three children who all study at the local public school and help their parents in their businesses. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy two oxen to plow her field

loans.name: Ren

texts.en: Mrs. Ren T. was born in 1982 and lives in Srae Vong village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She also sells Khmer cakes door to door. Her husband, Mr. Phoeurn Yorn, is a construction worker. Mrs. Ren T.'s problem is that she does not enough oxen to plow her field. To solve this problem, Mrs. Ren T. is seeking a loan to buy two oxen to plow the land. She is a mother of a child who is too small to work or study. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy two oxen to plow her field

loans.name: Srom's Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people comprise this village loan located in Prek Raing village, Kandal Province and led by Mrs. Srom M., 33, the village bank president  selected by the members. Each group member will use their portion of the loan to support their various businesses.

Srom is a Khmer cake seller in the local market while her husband, Mr. T. Tuy, is a fisherman, both occupations providing a small income that allows them to support their family. They have three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the other, age 3, is not yet in school.  In order to support her husband's fishing business, Srom is requesting a loan from AMK to buy a fishing machine.

loans.use: To buy a fishing machine for fishing

loans.name: Saroeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun C., 57, is the village bank president having been selected by its four members who are located in Preak Ta Pring village, Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their particular business.

Mrs. Saroeun C. is a farmer who owns a piece of land that she uses to cultivate onions. She is also a laborer who is able to earn a small salary to support her living.

In order to support her farming, Mrs. Saroeun C. will use the loan from AMK to buy fertilizer to cultivate green onions.

Mrs. Saroeun C. is widow and does not have any children.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate green onions

loans.name: Rom's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Rom L., 38, is the leader of this loan group having been selected by its four members who are located in Ampil Teouk village, Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their particular business.

Mrs. Rom L. and her husband, Mr. Chhorn Chhoeun, are farmers who own 1.4 hectares (3.5 acres) of land that they use to cultivate rice and peanuts for a living. With both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family.

In order to increase their income to improve the family living, Mrs. Rom L. will use the loan from AMK/Kiva to buy piglets to raise and pig feed.

This couple has four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a laborer, while the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and pig feed

loans.name: Sok Kunthea's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok Kunthea T., age 30, is a married woman and she is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its four members who all live in Ampil Toeuk village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their particular business.

Mrs. Sok Kunthea T. is a beef seller in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more beef to sell. Her husband, Mr. Toeuy Sru, is a construction worker and with both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family.

This couple has three children: one is attending the local school while the other two are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy more beef to sell

loans.name: Thy's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Thy M., 53, is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its four members who are located in Roluos village, Kandal province. The members will use their portion of the loan to buy equipment, supplies and other items for their individual purposes.

Mr. Thy M. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice for a living. For this farm, he will use the loan from AMK/Kiva to buy fertilizer to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Soeun Toem, is a seamstress in a garment factory and with both of these occupations, they are able to earn a small income to supP. their family.

This couple has four children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory and the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate rice

loans.name: Otgonchimeg

texts.en:
Otgonchimeg D. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. All of her children attend a local middle school, while her husband operates a truck transportation business in their town. The family has been living in Hovd province for 13 years now.

Otgonchimeg operates a clothing retail business out of her own movable stand at the local market. She started her business in 2005 and has found success in her trade. She has used her earnings to support her family and purchase a car and the stand in where she sells her clothing. In the future Otgonchimeg hopes to continue her success and grow her business line. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Mith's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mith S., age 52, is the leader of this loan group, having been selected by its five members who are located in Bat Lvea village, Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their own business.

Mrs. Mith S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice and she works very hard to support her two children. In order to increase her income to improve the family living, she will use the loan from AMK/Kiva to buy a cow for breeding.

Mrs. Mith S. is widow with two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and other is a laborer for the OMC company.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophorn I. is widow with a son who is a farmer and a barber. She lives in Trapeang Chrey village, Takeo province. She owns a general store in the local village, where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. She is also a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell and eat. 

Although she tries to work hard, she can only earn a little money. So to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Sophorn I. is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Samnang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Samnang P., age 50, is the leader of this group loan. She was selected by its five members, who all live in Preak Kat village in the Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Samnang P. stays at home and takes care her three children. Her husband, Mr. Sam Sok, is a house constructor who is able to earn a small profit to support his family. In order to support her husband's construction business, Mrs. Samnang P. will use the loan that she sought from AMK to buy construction supplies to build houses. 

This couple has three children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is car repairer while another one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to build houses

loans.name: Evelia Veneranda M

texts.es:
Evelia Hernández D. Y. es una gran modista que ha logrado no solo confeccionar ropa  sino también venderla   en su miscelánea, también  ubicada en la ciudadela 20 D. Julio, cerca al Estadio Metropolitano D. Barranquilla, epicentro D. donD. han salido muchos jugadores D. futbol representativos del armónico futbol que se juega en Colombia.
Evelia inició su actividad en el año 1999, antes D. este tiempo trabajaba como auxiliar D. enfermería pero desD. que se pensionó hace 3 años se ha convertido en una gran confeccionista y comerciante a la vez, trabaja diariamente por mas D. 8 horas y su clientela la conforman justamente excompañeros D. trabajo, vecinos familiares y referidos D. personas que conocen la calidad en su diseños y a las que le proporciona un plan D. pagos adecuado a sus necesidades.
Este es su tercer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo organización a la que está vinculada desD. hace mas  tres años, es decir desD. que empezó a desarrollar su capacidad emprendedora.
Su meta es y siempre ha sido contribuir en mejorar la calidad D. vida D. su familia y ascender en la escalera del éxito en su negocio que es lo que le ayudaría en este propósito. 
Con su credikiva comprará tela e hilos y también invertirá en mercancías como juegos D. sabanas, papelería y juguetería con el fin D. surtir su miscelánea para el segundo semestre del año que es D. mucho movimiento comercial.
texts.en:
Evelia Hernández D. Y. is a great stylist who not only makes clothing but also sells it in her general store, located in the "Ciudadela 20 D. Julio" neighborhood near the metropolitan stadium of Barranquilla, a sports center where there have been many soccer players representative of the high level of soccer played in Colombia. Evelia started her business in 1999. Before that she worked as a nursing assistant, but since she retired 3 years ago she has become a great garment producer and, at the same time, a great retailer. She works each day for more than 8 hours, and her customers incluD. her old work colleagues, neighbors, and people referred to her by those who know the quality of her designs. She provides her customers with a payment plan that meets their needs. This is her 3rd loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. She became affiliated with this organization about 3 years ago, which is when she started to develop her capacity as a businesswoman. Her goal is and has always been to make a contribution to improve the quality of life for her family, and to climb the ladder of success in her business, which is what helps her to achieve the first goal. With her loan from Kiva, she will buy fabric and thread, and will also invest in merchandise such as bed sheets, stationery and toys to restock her general store for the second half of the year when there is a lot of commercial activity.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: she will buy fabric and thread, and will also invest in merchandise such as sets of bed sheets, stationery and toys to restock her general store

loans.name: Nuris Del Carmen

texts.es: Nuris del Carmen M. y está dedicado al comercio de ropa calzado y cosmético entre otras variedades, ella tiene una miscelánea donde exhibe sus productos y que inició en el año 1992  pues anteriormente se dedicaba solo a su hogar. Vive en un sector muy cercano al escenario de futbol mas conocido en Colombia “El estadio Metropolitano de Barranquilla” donde coexisten zonas residenciales y comerciales, pues está rodeada de muchos negocios formales e informales que le generan una gran competencia, pero así mismo oportunidades de clientes potenciales, que si no encuentran lo que buscan recurren a su misceláneas, donde Nuris aplica como su estrategia mercadologica,  una atención oportuna y para sus clientes reales y rentables  planes de pago concertados y  de acuerdo con sus posibilidades  de responder a lo acreditado, porque lo cierto es que vende a crédito y de contado. Su clientela la conforman, vecinos, familiares, empleados y sobre todo está atenta a que estos sean recomendados por sus mejores clientes, lo cual le asegura un poco la recuperación de su dinero. Desde hace 3 años está vinculada a la Fundación Mario Santo domingo y desde ese momento ha logrado incrementar su cartera y surtirla, además desde ese momento ha podido responder de una manera oportuna al cliente, así sus utilidades se han incrementado y con ella ha logrado mejoras también para su hogar y es importante resaltar que su negocio genera un empleo. Su sueño actual es ver su miscelánea convertida en un almacén con un surtido de mercancías con la exclusividad que ameritan sus clientes. Requiere un Credikiva para comprar mercancía de contado y al por mayor especialmente ropa, calzado y cosméticos, porque quiere prepararse para el segundo semestre del años, pues es una temporada de gran movimiento comercial y siempre es bueno tener todo lo que el cliente necesita.
texts.en:
Nuris has a business selling clothes, shoes, and cosmetics, among other things; she has had a store since 1992 and before that she sold her products from home. She lives very close to a soccer stadium, around which there are residential as well as commercial neighborhoods full of stores and businesses that represent great competition for her, but also potential customers. If the customers don't find what they're looking for, they can always come in to Nuris' store, where she provides great customer service, including payment plans for her regular customers. Nuris' customers are her neighbors, family members and people at large. She pays special attention to those who have been referred to her by her regulars, which ensures good cash flow. Nuri has been involved with Kiva partner Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo for three years, which has helped her stock her business. Her relationship with FMSD has also helped her to respond quickly to her customers' needs, and has allowed her to make improvements to her home and provide employment for someone else. Nuris' dream is to turn her little business into a serious store, full of the exclusive items her customers deserve. She will use this loan to buy wholesale items such as clothes, shoes, and cosmetics in preparation for the second half of the year, the more active commercial season.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothes, shoes, and cosmetics to sell in her store

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
In Angkonh village, Takeo province, lives a person named Mr. Ly S., who was born in 1977. He is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support his family; moreover, he is also a motorbike broker. 

His wife, Mrs. Bach Chea, is a seamstress in a garment factory, where she gets a low salary to support her family. Although they try to work hard, they can make only a little money. So to improve conditions for his family, Mr. Ly S. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. 

He is a father of two children, both of whom are too young to work or study. His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Koem Ly's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Koem Ly C., age 68, is the leader of this group loan. She was selected by the four members, who all live in Ou Romchek village in the Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Koem Ly C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land in which to cultivate vegetables for a living. She works very hard to support a child. She will use the loan that she sought from AMK to buy fertilizers and pesticide to cultivate vegetables. 

Mrs. Koem Ly C. is widow with a child, who is also a farmer and supports her mother on the farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate vegetables

loans.name: Aun

texts.en: Aun E. is married to Thav Long, and she lives in the village of Angkonh in the province Takeo. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land, on which she cultivates rice to sell to support her family; her husband is a motorbike taxi driver. They try to work hard, but they earn little money to support their family. In order to improve this condition, Aun E. is seeking a loan to buy a cow, and with the rest of the loan she will buy ten piglets to start a new breeding business. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are studying in local public school, while the others are too small to work or study. Her husband is pictured in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Elgie

texts.en: Elgie B. is a single woman who lives in Manghilao, Barangay Masaba, Danao City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating an abaca (fiber from abaca palm leaf used for handicraft production) weaving business. Elgie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Elgie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,200, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her third loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase more products used for her abaca weaving business so that she could continue to save up for the future and help the family by improving their living conditions. Elgie B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team page and become a part of our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sambour's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambour T., age 53, is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its four members who all live in Preak Ta Pring village in Kandal province. All members will use their portions of the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Sambour T. is a grocery seller in the local village and is able to earn a small income to support her two children. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it and decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Mrs. Sambour T. is a widow with two children, who are students and help their mother with her business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell

loans.name: Bunthoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Bunthoeun M. (pictured with his wife on the corn farm) and his wife, Mrs. Houn Duch, married in 1986 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Three of them married, two of whom live in the family home, one lives in a separate home, and another one attends school. 

Bunthoeun and his wife are farmers. They grow rice and different kinds of vegetables such as corn, potato, jicama and yam. Bunthoeun received a previous Kiva loan, and is now asking for another loan of $1,000 to buy seeds, pesticides, and fertilizer to maintain his rice and vegetable farm. He will also buy piglets for his wife to raise. The couple will be able to earn extra income from the new business.

loans.use: To use for farming and to buy piglets for his wife to raise.

loans.name: Ngorn

texts.en:
Mr. Ngorn T., 46, and his wife, Mrs. Chroeb In, 40, have been married for more than 20 years and have one son and one daughter. The family lives along National Road Number Five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Ngorn was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured instead. 

Ngorn has been driving a motor taxi for 20 years, while his wife has been a garment factory worker for 20 years. Besides the motor taxi business, the couple also farms, growing rice on their farmland in the village when they have time. 

They always spend a lot of money on plowing fees; it’s difficult for them to provide enough income to support their family. Hence, Ngorn is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase cows to use for plowing.

loans.use: To purchase cows to use for plowing.

loans.name: Koeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Koeun H. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Son Sut, live on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1978 and have 8 children: 6 sons and 2 daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home, one is a garment factory worker, one has full-time employment, and two others attend school.

Koeun has been a silk weaver for more than 40 years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in the Phnom Penh market. Mr. Son Sut is a farmer.

Koeun is requesting a loan of USD100 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sokky

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokky S. (pictured above), and her husband, Mr. Sok-An Chheng, live on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1990 and have four children: one son and three daughters. 

Sokky has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a policeman for more than twenty years. She is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sophon's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 14 villagers from  Chrouy Pisei village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Sophon C., 40, has been selected as the village bank president by the other members. She is a farmer who owns one hectare of land for cultivating rice. She will use the loan to buy a grass-cutting machine for cutting vegetation on her farm.  Aside from being a farmer, she also sews clothes for sale, while her husband, Mr. Sambok Kong, is a teacher in the local school. With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. The couple has six children; two are at home and support their mother farming, while the other four are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a grass-cutting machine for her farm

loans.name: Savuth's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Savuth U., 48, is the village bank president, having been selected by its fourteen members who all live in Chrouy Pisei village in Kandal province. All members of this village bank will use their portions of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mr. Savuth U. is a bicycle repairer in the local village and, through this business, he is able to earn a small income to support his family. In order to maintain this service, he will use the loan from AMK / Kiva to buy bicycle supplies for his business. His wife, Mrs. Lalin Dy, is a stay-at-home mother and she takes care of her five children. Two children are seamstresses in the garment factory, one is a vehicle driver and the other two attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy bicycle supplies for his business

loans.name: Sam Ann's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Ann L., age 62, is the village bank president, having been selected by its ten members who all live in Ta Hing village in Kandal province. All members of this village group will use their portions of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Sam Ann L. and her husband, Mr. Vong Chum, are farmers who own 2-hectares of land to cultivate rice and vegetables. They work very hard to support their family. Aside from farming, Mrs. Sam Ann L. also sells vegetables at the local market and is able to earn a small income to improve her family's life. Mrs. Sam Ann L. will use the loan she requested from AMK to buy more vegetables to sell. This couple has four children: two are construction workers and two are laborers.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Khorn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Khorn K., age 54, is the president selected by the nine members of the village bank loan who all live in Ta Hing village in Kandal province. All members of this group will use their portions of the loan to support their different businesses.  

Mrs. Khorn K. and her husband, Mr. Horn Oem, are farmers who own 2 hectares of land to cultivate vegetables and rice for a living. They work very hard to support their family. This couple has six children: three are seamstresses in a garment factory, one is a laborer and the other two are students who also help their parents with the farming. Mrs. Khorn K. will use the loan from AMK to add to her savings to fix up her house.

loans.use: To add to her savings to fix up her house

loans.name: Keom Youn's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Keom Youn R., age 64, is the president selected by the four members of this village bank loan who all live in Lech Buon village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use her portion of the loan to support her own business.

Mrs. Keom Youn R. and her husband, Mr. Sary Doeuk, are Khmer noodle sellers in the local village. With this business, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. To maintain the business, Mrs. Keom Youn R. will use this loan from AMK to build a food stand to sell Khmer noodles. This couple has five children: one is a police officer, two are seamstresses in a garment factory, one works in a company and one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To build a food stand for Khmer noodle selling

loans.name: Reak Smey

texts.en:
Mrs. Reak Smey S., age 45, lives in Kampong Samnanh village in Kandal province. She is widow with a child who is age 4 and is not yet in school.

Mrs. Reak Smey S. is a seamstress in a garment factory and she also sells groceries in the local market. With both of these occupations, she is able to earn a small income to support her family.

In order to support her grocery business, Mrs. Reak Smey S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities

loans.name: Jazgul's Group

texts.en:
Jazgul T. is the leader of the group. She is 33, married, and has a six year old daughter. To make money, Jazgul and her husband sell fruits and vegetables in the market. They have been doing it for ten years, and earn 15,600 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase some land in the village. With this loan, Jazgul wants to purchase fruits and vegetables (potatoes, cucumbers, strawberries) in order to resell them at a higher price in the market. In the future she wants to expand her business and save some money to purchase a flat.

Sagyndyk A., 70, is married. He has two daughters, and both of them work in a sewing workshop. Eight years ago, with the initial investment of 8,000 soms, Sagyndyk purchased ten goats. He resold all of them for 17,000 soms. And now, he hopes to obtain a loan to purchase cattle for breeding.

Nazira K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 43 and married. She has a daughter, who is 23 and works as a waitress. Nazira works as a nurse, and she also resells silver to make some money. She started this activity a year ago with the initial investment of 8,700 soms and now she makes 6,000 soms per month. Nazira applied for the loan, because she needs more money to purchase silver in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to expand her business and purchase a big house.

Anarkan S. is 39 and married. She has two sons, and both of them are at school. In order to make money, Nazira works in a sewing workshop. With this loan, she wants to repair her house.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida C. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Pangpang, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a rice retailing business. Her husband Jeremias C., age 53, earns a living as a construction worker and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have six children who are 16 to 25 years old. Aida joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Aida has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 18,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 5,000 PHP; thus, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP to buy more rice. She will use the profits to meet basic everyday needs as well as allowance for the kids to go to school and for medicine for her sick mother-in-law. All the while, she is trying her best to continue to save up for the future. Aida C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Rima

texts.en:
Rima is a 45 year old married woman with two kids. Rima owns a bakery, which is the source of the majority of her family's income. Rima has specialized in a special baking quality for six years, and still maintains the same quality.

This is Rima’s second cycle with Al Majmoua, and she proved to be a person who keeps her promise by paying back on schedule and as expected. This time, Rima has requested a Loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy primary materials necessary for her business, such as flour, oil and salt. Rima helps her husband provide for their family's income and their household expenses, and she’s proud of what she has achieved, because raising a family nowadays is very hard and expensive for people who care about their kids' future and education. Rima dreams of a big famous bakery that everyone knows and visits.

loans.use: To buy primary materials necessary for her business.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina C. is a 49-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: tricycle and fish-vending businesses. She lives in Blk. 9, Sta. Cruz Heights, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Marina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her tricycle and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income income of 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Marina is borrowing 13,000 PHP so she can repair her house and pay off the remaining balance on the tricycle she purchased. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 11,000 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Marina hopes to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. loans.name: Asel

texts.en:
Asel J. is a resident of Tup, a small town in the Isykul region, with a population of 15,000 people. She is 37 and married. She has three sons and two daughters. All the children are students.

Asel is an entrepreneur and her husband is a bookkeeper. Three years ago, with the initial investment of 15,000 soms, Asel rented a store and began to sell convenience goods. She now makes 10,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase that store. And now she has applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase various goods (100 kg of sugar, 300 kg of macaroni, 10 packs of drinks, and 300 kg of confectioneries) to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, Asel wants to expand her business, save money, and purchase a two-floor house.

Her husband Federico O., who is 58 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have six children who are 19 to 31 years old. Nelita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nelita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 21,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 16th loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use to purchase a refrigerator for her sari-sari (general) store and also to add to her revolving working capital, so that she can continue to save up for future additional capital for both businesses. Nelita O. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. She has three daughters; two older daughters are at school and the youngest one is not yet. In 2008, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, Almagul started to sell convenience goods. loans.name: Addah

texts.en:
Addah A. O. is forty years old and is married with two children aged thirteen years and ten years old. Addah’s business is located at Kiandutu, a very busy market in Thika which is the region in Kenya known for its production of pineapples.

Addah makes clothes at her tailoring shop and sells them to local customers. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers; hence customers are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

Addah is using her Kes 50,000 loan to buy another sewing machine and more materials for making clothes to grow her business and be able to serve her customers more efficiently.

In future, Addah sees herself going back to college to get more training on tailoring and dressmaking, opening her own training school, and having a big boutique in the central business district of Thika. She describes herself as very hardworking.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine and more materials for making clothes

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en:

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is a single mother with three children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes food, rent and school fees.

Constance owns a store in Naguru selling charcoal which she buys in bags from Luwero and Nakasongola districts. She uses her own lorry (truck) to and from buying charcoal. She has been in this business for over ten years, selling in Naguru market. She works six days a week and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. Her only business challenge is the rainy season when the roads becomes impassable.

Constance joined MCDT because of the low interest rate it charged. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She is aspiring to own another delivery van.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George N. N. is twenty-five years old, is single, and does not have any children yet.

George’s business is located at Ruiru in Thika town. Thika is the region in Kenya known for its production of pineapples. He sells sweets (candies), batteries, paper bags, steel wire, lotions, detergents and other items. He hawks his items (goes door-to-door) and has been doing this business for two years now.

George says that this business is profitable and the major challenges he has are financial constraints. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well.

George is using his Kes 70,000 loan to buy a motorcycle to enable him to hawk his goods more easily. He hopes to own his own shop some day. He is very hardworking and innovative.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to help him hawk his goods

loans.name: Shadrack

texts.en:
Shadrack O. A. is thirty-two years old, is single, and does not have any children yet. His business is located at a busy estate in Mombasa known as Barsheba. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well-known for its many many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean’s white beaches.

Shadrack owns a general store near the residential area known by the name Shad. He has been selling such items as rice, flour, oil, detergents, sugar and other items to the local people for the last seven years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that he has to run the business all by himself because he believes that it always needs his supervision. Thus, he is not able to attend to many other personal matters as all his time is spent in the business.

Shadrack is using his Kes 60,000 loan to buy more general items to expand his business. He hopes to diversify and grow a tour company which he has already started. He says he has initiative and describes himself as innovative and smart.

loans.use: To increase his stock of flour, sugar, oil, snacks and detergents

This loan will be her second from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.
