loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina G. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Tinago, Bgry. Anahaw, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  raising oysters and farming. Her husband Mateo G., 58 years old, helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 8 children who are 23 to  34 years old. 

Florentina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florentina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for the future of her business and family. The accompanying photo of Florentina and her husband in their wooden boat was taken near the raft where they raise oysters. Florentina G. is a 'Dungganon' woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Lene

texts.en:
Lene A. is a 53-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures:  general store and food vending businesses. She lives in Brgy. Magballo, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental.

She is a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and food vending businesses, Lene is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 6,000 Php. 

Lene is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she can buy more stock for her general store, and she also intends to use part of her loan to buy fishing gear to start a fishing business.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of P19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lene aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  'Dungganon' way.

loans.name: Jelyn's Group

texts.en:
Jelyn P. is from the village of Sepac Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old. Jelyn is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Shasta Daisy 1'.

Jelyn is single and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Jelyn owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling herbal products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling herbal products like "haplas", & "bemar" in the local community. Jelyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jelyn is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Jelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Mtu-Mbeyi Group

texts.en:
Selemani S., 23, is married and an auctioneer in the Ilala market just some few kilometers from the city centre.  For seven years he has worked from 5am to 10am daily.  He is able to make a monthly profit of about $375.

This will be Selemani’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loan to increase his business stock and he has paid back the loan successfully.  He hopes for a new loan to increase his stock even more. His dreams is to open a retail shop and sell things like wheat flour, sugar, flour, cooking oil, salt and other edibles.
	
S. will share this loan with his loan group Mtu-Mbei which totals 16 members.  Members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. 

S. is in the front row wearing a white cap.

loans.name: Abagwaneza Group

texts.fr:
Salvator N. est un commerçant âgé de 37 ans qui habite la Commune urbaine de Kamenge en Mairie de Bujumbura. Il fait le commerce de produits vivriers de boutique comme le riz, le haricot, et autres articles  au quartier Kamenge il ya de cela 4 ans. Il a fait ses études primaires jusqu’en 6e année. Il était cultivateur avant de commencer cette activité. Il n’habite pas avec tous les membres de sa famille exceptes ses enfants qu’il héberge ou il loue une maison dans Kamenge. Son épouse, Monique N., est cultivatrice et habite la campagne. Il arrive au 5e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Il a 4 enfants qui étudient.
  
Il demande le crédit Kiva pour  acheter de grandes quantités des produits vivriers de boutique dans l’espoir de réaliser un grand bénéfice. Il est souvent maladif et se trouve parfois menacé par les voleurs qui emportent ses biens. Il espère qu’avec du bénéfice généré de ce crédit dans le futur, il sera à mesure d’acheter une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison et rester avec son propre capital. 

 Il est un des membres du groupe  communautaire« Abagwaneza ».
texts.en:
Salvator N. is a 37-year-old merchant living in the Kamenge urban borough, part of Bujumbura Mayorship. He has been retailing food products such as rice, beans, and other such products in the Kamenge borough for the past four years. He completed schooling up to 6th grade. He was a farmer before starting this commercial activity. The only family members he lives with are his children for whom he rents a house in Kamenge. His four children all attend school. His wife, Monique N., is a crop farmer and lives in the country. He has now reached the 5th group loan cycle with the Turame association. He is requesting the Kiva loan to buy large quantities of food products with the hope of generating much profit. He is often unwell and is sometimes threatened by thieves who take his belongings. He hopes that the revenue generated by this credit loan will enable him in the future to buy a lot, build his own home and build up some capital. He is one of the members of the "Abagwaneza” community group.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy large quantities of food products with the hope of generating much profit

They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Gesila

texts.en:
Gesila C. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Arbor, Boljoon, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store business. Her 52 year old husband, Romolo C., works as a taxi driver to earn his living. They have 4 children, 11 to 20 years old. 

Gesila joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 9 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gesila has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 10th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 which she intends to use expand her general store so that she can continue to save up for the family's future and to improve their way of life. Gesila C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Victoire

texts.fr: O. Victoire est née le 23 Décembre 1967 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUNLIHO Charles, un électricien, Victoire est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Victoire vit avec sa famille à Hêvié, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, depuis une dizaine d'année. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Victoire n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Victoire vend divers produits (conserves de tomate et de sardine, lait, sucre, pâtes alimentaires, savons, allumettes, riz, etc.) à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Victoire vend des poteries. Victoire s'approvisionne à Tori et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Victoire exerce cette activité depuis quatre ans et a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Victoire désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et agrandir son activité ; raison pour laquelle Victoire sollicite un deuxième prêt en vue de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. Plus tard, Victoire désire ouvrir un autre point de vente au marché de Cococodji, en vue de se faire d'autres revenus.
texts.en:
Victoire Odountain was born 23 December 1967 in Ouidah, a historic city of Benin. Married to Charles Houliho, an electrician, Victoire is the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school. For the past ten years, she has been living with her family in Hêvié, in the Abomey Calvi municipality. The couple shares responsibility for family expenses. Victoire has not attended school. To make ends meet, she sells various products from her home (canned tomatoes and sardines, milk, sugar, pasta, soap, matches, rice, etc.). As a side business, she also sells crockery. She gets her supplies from Tori and Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Victoire has been running her business for four years, and has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which she reimbursed in full. She wishes to increase her stock supply and expand her activity, which is why she requesting a second loan so that she can better respond to customer demand. In the future, Victoire would like to open another point of sales at the Cococodji market, to become an additional source of income.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 10 cartons of sugar, 2 dozen boxes of milk, pasta, and crockery.

loans.name: Clémence

texts.fr: B. Clémence est née vers 1971 à Hozin au BENIN. Mariée à HOUNKPONOU, Clémence est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Clémence vit avec son mari et ses enfants depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Sègbèya à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Clémence assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Clémence n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Clémence vend divers produits (conserves de tomates et de sardine, vinaigrette, mayonnaise, sucre, lait, huile, bougies, pâtes alimentaires, œufs , farine de manioc, et les condiments de sauce) dans sa boutique située à son domicile. Clémence exerce comme activité secondaire le vente de charbons de bois. Clémence est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu antérieurement trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Clémence désire augmenter son fonds de roulement et élever le niveau de son activité afin de se faire plus de revenus. C'est ce qui l'a conduit à solliciter un nouveau crédit.
texts.en:
Clemence B. was born in 1971 in Hozin, Benin. Married to Hounkponou, Clemence is the mother of four children, all attending (or having attended) school. For the past ten years, she has been living with her husband and children in the Sègbèya borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She shares responsibility for family expenses with her husband. Clemence has only attended primary school. To make ends meet, she sells various products in a shop located in her home (canned tomatoes and sardines, salad dressing, mayonnaise, sugar, milk, vegetable oil, candles, pasta, eggs, cassava flour, and sauce condiments). She also sells charcoal as a side business. Clemence is a regular ALIDé client, having already been granted three previous loans, all successfully reimbursed. Facing increasing demands from her customers, she wishes to increase her working capital and raise the level of her activity so as to generate more revenue. This is what prompted her to request another loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 26 years.

Elena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Elena is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Elena from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita S. is from the village of Galas, Dipolog City. She is 63 years old and is widowed with four adult children. Rosita owns and operates a business raising ducks for sale. She is just starting this business. In 2006, Rosita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 6,500 PHP which will be used to purchase chicks and materials for raising poultry. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Ludivina

Ludivina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ludivina is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to finish her kitchen. This loan will be her third from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. loans.name: Sala

texts.en: Sala J. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal at home, and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Sala is 54 years old and is widowed. She has 7 children and 3 of them go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Tessie

texts.en:
Ma. Tessie C. is from the village of Gusa. She is 42 years old and is married with five school-aged children.

Ma. Tessie owns and operates a business selling vegetables. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Ma. Tessie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business.

Ma. Tessie is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital to purchase more vegetables to sell. This loan will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Nhelajean has been engaged in her business for more than seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Nhelajean is requesting a new loan of 3,500 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nhelajean from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 57 years old. Emma is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emma also shared that from her income from the farm, she was able to put up a sari-sari store, where she sells stuff like sugar, vinegar, and many other goods. She hopes that her store will grow as well.

Emma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Emma is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and additional store inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is 38 years old and married to a driver. The couple is blessed with three children who are in school. She is a member of Gathiruini B group whose members are dairy farmers. The members share business ideas and also guarantee each other's loans.

Charity owns and runs a retail shop and does dairy farming. She previously practiced arable farming. She has nine years of experience in farming and has seen her business grow. She has requested her second loan of 40,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to buy a dairy cow, construct a feeding tank, and add stock in her shop. She hopes to expand her business so as to improve her living standards. In ten years, she wants to have expanded her retail shop into wholesale.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow, construct a feeding tank, and add stock in her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 28 years old, married and has a child. He graduated from intermediate school. 

The borrower is a baker. He will use this loan to purchase a kneading machine, flour and another clay oven. 

The borrower has a wealth of experience and works continuously. He has a good reputation in the market and many clients buy bread from him because his bakery is clean and fresh. He has two workers working with him.

loans.use: To buy a kneading machine, flour, and a clay oven

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 26 year old member of Jiinue group in Faulu Kenya. He has a transport business, and is also a farmer who rears dairy cattle. He has been saving his money with the group members. This has helped him to invest in his business which is only three months old. He has requested a loan of 25,000 KES to add a dairy cow so as to increase milk production. He hopes to own trucks for his transport business. He describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lallen

texts.en:
Lallen A., from the village of Delapa, Sibutad, is 38 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lallen owns and operates a a general store selling basic household items in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lallen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC that was used as additional capital for her business, she is now requesting a new loan, her third, of 7,000 PHP to purchase new stock for the store.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Juliette

texts.en: Juliette is 42 years old and married with a three year old child. She has been operating a retail shop for three years. She sells mainly cereals, sugar, salt, maize flour, and cooking fat in her shop. She has been an active member of a group in Faulu Kenya, and attends the weekly meetings regularly.  Being a member of the group, she can easily access loans from Faulu Kenya. Therefore, she has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to purchase a weighing machine and cereals. She hopes to expand her shop in five years.

loans.use: To purchase a weighing machine and cereals.

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 43 years old. Jeannette is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jeannette owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising ducks for sale. Jeannette has been engaged in her business for over 2 years. She also helps her husband maintain their rice farm. She also helps sell their harvest to the market.

Jeannette joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeannette has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jeannette is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. She also plans to buy farm inputs. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Jeannette from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is 29 years old, married, and blessed with three children who go to school. He joined Tushikane Pamoja group as a businessman who runs a garage. He also has a video library which he runs so as to earn extra income. He previously took out a loan worth 20,000 KES, which he used to boost the business and successfully repaid it. He has requested for 40,000 KES to buy machines and tools for repairing vehicles. He hopes to buy a plot in the future.

loans.use: To buy machines and tools for repairing vehicles.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony is 29 years old and a father of one. He owns a van which he uses for a transport business. He has engaged in the transport business for four years. He also runs a retail shop together with his wife. He is a member of Mwangaza group in Faulu Kenya, whose members are accountable for each member who takes out a loan. He previously took out a loan of 20,000 KES, which he used to buy a van together with his brother. He has requested for a loan of 40,000 KES to paint the vehicle, pay licenses, and replace the seats. He hopes to own at least three vans in the future so as to get more income.

loans.use: To paint the vehicle, pay licenses, and replace the seats.

loans.name: Diane

texts.fr: Née en 1976, A. Diane est mariée à DANSOU D. Clément, un mécanicien. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, dont un représente leur enfant. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Diane vit depuis neuf ans avec sa famille à Ménontin, un quartier de Cotonou capitale économique du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Diane exerce comme activité la vente de nourriture (riz, haricot, accompagné de sauce aux poissons et viandes, etc.) et de façon secondaire, Diane vend des boissons. Diane achète ses produits vivriers à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et se ravitaille en boissons dans les dépôts de Cotonou. Par contre, Diane vend sa nourriture à Fifadji à Cotonou. Diane exerce cette activité depuis quatre ans et a déjà obtenu quatre prêts qui ont été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Diane sollicite un autre prêt en vue d'augmenter sa production journalière et d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire.
texts.en:
Born in 1976, Diane A. is married to D. Clément Dansou, a mechanic. The couple has four children to care for, of whom one is their own child. All the children attend (or have attended) school. For the past 9 years Diane has been living with her family in the Ménontin borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The couple share responsibilities for the family expenses. Having never been to school, Diane’s commercial activity is to sell food preparations (rice, beans, accompanied by fish- or meat-based sauces, etc.). As a side business, she also sells beverages. Diane gets her food supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and her beverages from depots in Cotonou. On the other hand, she sells her food preparations in the Fifadji area of Cotonou. Diane has been running her business for four years and was already granted four loans, all repaid in full. Given the increasing demands from her customers, she is requesting another loan so that she can increase her daily production and generate higher turnover.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and beans, sauce condiments and beverages

loans.name: Jessette

texts.en:
Jessette D. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 21 years old. Jessette is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Jessette owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jessette has been engaged in her business for over 3 years.

Jessette joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessette has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jessette is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jessette from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Adonai Plus Group

texts.en:
“Adonai Plus” is a group of 19 owners of small businesses chaired by Mbuyi. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.

Mbuyi T. is 25 years old and single. He runs a cellphone booth and sells prepaid cards. He has been a micro entrepreneur since 2007. He is working hard because his ambition is to open a shop and become financially self-sufficient. The loan he’ll obtain next will be used to diversify his business, by buying phone accessories to resell with the aim of increasing the profits. Mbuyi makes a profit of about $42 per week. His business is located to the south-west of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To purchase phone accessories for resale at profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Nurbek

texts.en:
Nurbek M. (42) was born in the south of Kyrgyzstan. Cattle-breeding was the only means of subsistence for his large family. After graduating from secondary school, Nurbek became a tractor driver and helped his family in farming. In 1990, Nurbek got married and during the following three years he became the father of two daughters. In 1992, Nurbek decided to devote his life to maintenance of public order, and got a job as a policeman in a local police office. After two years, Nurbek was promoted to the position of inspector in a juvenile colony in Voznesenovka village, where he worked for 16 years. During these years, his family went through some difficult times – his newly born son died, and his wife went through a complex heart surgery and now requires up to 5,000 Kyrgyz Soms every month for heart medication. Recently, Nurbek retired from the police. Unfortunately, the pension in public order authorities is low (only 3,000 Kyrgyz Soms) and Nurbek decided to start a business in animal breeding.

Using his starting capital of 10,000 Kyrgyz Soms, Nurbek bought 5 goats, and after one year he broadened his business with one dairy cow, two horses and one bull. Nurbek plans to use this loan of 100,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy four bulls and one dairy cow.

Speaking of his plans for the future, Nurbek dreams of establishing his own minifarm with large numbers of cattle. He also wishes to buy a car some day and take his family on a good vacation.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Joefemia

texts.en:
Joefemia D. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 30 years old. Joefemia is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Joefemia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Joefemia has been engaged in her business for over 12 years. She wishes to have a successful business and for her children to finish college and have a bright future.

Joefemia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joefemia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Joefemia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Joefemia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: William

texts.en: William is 26 years old, married, and has a three year old child. He has been selling milk for four years to earn a living, but was previously employed.  He packs milk in polythene paper bags and he hopes to get his milk packed in decent containers in the future. This will help him market his products in a better way. His main challenge is lack of proper storage facility. Hence, he has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to purchase a refrigerator. He hopes to own a big shop to sell milk in five years.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator.

loans.name: Reine

texts.fr: Née en 1972, D. Reine est mariée à un polygame et a deux enfants à charge. Aucun enfant n'est scolarisé. Reine vit depuis neuf ans environs au quartier Ménontin à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, avec son mari et les deux enfants à charge. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins du ménage. Reine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Il y a près de cinq ans que Reine mène comme activité la restauration. Reine prépare et vend en effet de la nourriture (riz, haricot, pâte de maïs, accompagné de condiments de sauce) et aussi des boissons à Agla à Cotonou. Reine achète ses produits vivriers à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et s'approvisionne en boissons dans les dépôts de Cotonou. Reine a déjà bénéficié de quatre prêts à ALIDé et les a tous bien remboursés. Reine désire élever davantage le niveau de son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Reine sollicite un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1972, Reine D. is married to a polygamous husband and has two children under her care. None of her children attend school. Reine has been living for the past nine years in the Ménontin borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, with her husband and the two children. The couple shares responsibility for family expenses. Reine has not attended school. For the past five years she has been active in the food preparation business. She prepares and sells food (rice, beans, corn paste, accompanied by sauce condiments) and also beverages, in the Agla area of Cotonou. Reine gets her food products from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and gets her beverages from depots in Cotonou. Reine has already received four loans from ALIDé and has fully repaid all of them. She wants to increase her activity level and improve customer satisfaction, which is why she is requesting another loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sauce condiments, rice, beans, corn and beverages

loans.name: Pierrine

texts.en: Pierrine is 30 years old and engaged to be married. She has one child who is 2 years old, and her fiance is a businessman. She sells bed sheets, bed covers, and clothing in the local market. In the 8 years that she has had the business, she has become known for selling quality products. With some of the profits from her business, she has been able to purchase health insurance for herself and her child. With the loan she wants to buy higher quality bed covers and clothing.  ith the profits, she plans to buy more food and a greater variety of food for her family. She also hopes to invest some of the profits in developing her business.

loans.use: To buy more bed sheets and bedcovers.

loans.name: Qudrat

texts.en: Qudrat M. is a 42 year old man who keeps his own café in Bilasuavr city. He is married and has 2 children. Qudrat has two years of experience in this field and has already gained a good reputation among local people, and that is the reason why his café is always full of people. Qudrat applied for 800 AZN and will use this loan to improve the conditions of his café and make a small renovation.

loans.use: To make renovations of his cafe.

loans.name: Qadir

texts.en: Qadir N. is a 53-year-old man who has been breeding cattle for the last 10 years. He is married and has four children.  He buys young cattle, raises them and sells for a profitable price. Now he would like to buy five sheep and start breeding them. Qadir applied for 1,000 AZN for this purpose. Sheep breeding is a very profitable business and Qadir has deep experience in breeding them as well as breeding cattle.

loans.use: To purchase five sheep and one calf

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married man who has four children. Three of the children are still attending school. He has several years of experience operating a grocery shop in his town. He has one child working as an employee in a company and he helps him in the household. He offers food products, cereals, soft drinks etc. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,200 to increase his shop merchandise. He is looking to continue expanding his business and to further increase his productivity. He expects that his business will continue to be successful in the coming year.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To increase his shop merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 45 years old, married and has two children. He graduated from intermediate school. 

The borrower will use this loan to develop his carpentry shop and purchase a sawing machine and wood. The borrower has been working in this field for five years and gained lots of experience and expertise. Because he does a good job, he has many clients. The borrower has a good reputation in the market.

loans.use: To buy a sawing machine and wood

loans.name: Georgette Gisèle

texts.fr: D. Georgette Gisèle est née en 1955 et vit depuis trente deux ans à Sodjèatimè, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Georgette Gisèle est une veuve et mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont actuellement à sa charge. Georgette Gisèle vit seule avec ses enfants et assure leurs charges. Georgette Gisèle n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis une vingtaine d'année, Georgette Gisèle vend de l'huile d'arachide à son domicile, ce qui lui permet de faire face à ses besoins. Georgette Gisèle s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui avait obtenu quatre crédits et qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Georgette Gisèle désire augmenter son stock de produits et diversifier son activité par la vente de pièces de rechanges ; raison pour laquelle Georgette Gisèle sollicite un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Georgette Gisèle D. was born in 1955 and has been living for the past 32 years in the Sodjèatimè borough of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Georgette Gisèle is a widow and the mother of three children, all attending (or having attended) school, and of whom two are currently under her care. Georgette Gisèle lives alone with her children and is their sole provider. Georgette Gisèle has only attended primary school. She has been selling peanut oil from her home over the past twenty years, which enables her to meet her needs. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. She is a regular client of ALIDé, having been granted four loans, all of which were duly repaid. She wishes to increase her stock of products and diversify her offerings by retailing spare parts, which is the reason she is requesting another loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy containers of peanut oil and spare parts

loans.name: Odinahon's Group

texts.en:
Odinahon Z. is the leader of her group. She is 33 and married. She has three sons and all of them are in school. Three years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Odinahon and her husband began to breed livestock and sell it after fattening for a higher price. In this way, they make 4,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Odinahon wants to purchase sheep for breeding. In the future, she is planning to increase the number of livestock and save money to be able to pay for her children’s education at the university.

Gulnara J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 35 and married. She has three daughters and a son and all of them study at school. Seven years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, Gulnara and her husband started to breed cattle. By selling the cattle after fattening, they make 4,000 soms per month.  Gulnara applied for the loan because she wants to purchase a bull and resell it at a higher price after fattening. 

Almazbek A., 29, is married. He has two sons and a daughter and all of them are preschool age (In Kyrgyzstan, children go to school when they are seven). Four years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, Almazbek rented a place and started to sell convenience goods. He makes 4,000 soms per month.  With the money received from the loan, he wants to purchase foodstuffs to increase the turnover of his business. In the future, Almazbek plans to expand his business and wants to build a big house.

Ulpat K., 44, is married. She has two daughters and two sons. The older daughter and her Dad went to work in Russia to make some money, and the other children are students.  Six years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 soms, Ulpat rented a place and started to sell convenience goods. She makes 8,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to repair her house and pay for her children’s education. Ulpat also breeds livestock and now the price for livestock is low. So with money received from the loan, she wants to purchase sheep for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Natiq

texts.en: Natiq A. is a 29-year-old man who breeds and sells cattle and sheep in Bilasuvar city. He has nine years of experience in this field. Natiq is married and has three children. He buys calves and lambs, fattens them, and then sells them for a profit to the local butchers, cafes and in the livestock bazaar. His monthly income is about 200-400 AZN.  He applied for 1,000 AZN to purchase one milking cow and fodder. He believes this loan will increase his profit and improve his family life.

loans.use: To purchase one milking cow and fodder

loans.name: Nazeli

texts.en: Nazeli M. lives in Ijevan, Armenia with her husband and a son. Her daughter is married and lives separately from her parents. For about 10 years Nazeli has run a clothing sales business in Ijevan Central market, the proceeds from which paid for her children’s education and helps her husband to support their family. Nazeli is now requesting a 600.000 AMD loan to buy an  assortment of women’s and men’s summer clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy an assortment of women’s and men’s summer clothes to resell

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en: Rosalia is 40 years old and a mother of four.  To earn a living, she sells clothes.  She has been engaged in the business for five years.  She is also a dressmaker.  Rosalia, who is a widow, works hard to educate her children so that they have a brighter future.  She is a member of Mumbuni Wa Mundu group in Faulu Kenya whose members guarantee each other's loan.  She has requested a loan of 30,000 KES. to buy more clothes.  She dreams of opening a boutique in the future.  She describes herself as a hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Bahar

texts.en: Bahar A. is a 50-year-old woman who has been breeding poultry for the last 10 years. She is married and has five children. Bahar sells her chicken and turkey to the local restaurants and, once every two weeks, her husband sells poultry in the livestock bazaar. Bahar`s monthly income is 150-200 AZN. Now she would like to expand her business and purchase sheep. She applied for 1,000 AZN to buy chickens and six sheep.

loans.use: To purchase poultry and six sheep

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson is 24 years old.  He started selling clothes one year ago.  He has become more focused in his business since he joined Faulu Kenya.  He hopes that someday he will start importing clothes for resale.

He has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy more clothes.  He believes that, with an increase of stock, his business will fetch more income.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 27 years old, married and has a three year old child.  He has been offering motorbike transport for two years.  He is able to raise the family with the income from his business.

He is a member of a group in Faulu Kenya.  In the group, he saves his money on a weekly basis.  The members also share business ideas.

Michael has been guaranteed a loan of 20,000 KES.  This will be his first loan from Faulu Kenya and he will use the money to purchase a motorbike.  In the future, he hopes to buy a car for a taxi business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old divorced woman with one child. After the break up she decided to take on the responsibilities for her child, so she opened a beauty salon in 2006 after having 6 years of experience as a hairdresser. As she said, she always tries to offer all the new cuts and models to meet the requests of her customers and to attract more clients to her shop. Today, she is asking to borrow $1,200 to expand her business by adding new services and purchasing more equipment and beauty supplies. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in her picture, not indicating her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support of Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in microfinance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit partners.kivaorg/partners/115

loans.use: Adding new services, purchasing more equipment and beauty supplies

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 26 years old and married with one child. For the last four years, she has been rearing poultry for commercial use and selling eggs to retailers. Mary appreciates Kiva partner, Faulu Kenya, for motivating her to work hard in her business. This is because she has to pay her weekly dues together with her group members. She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy chicks. She hopes to expand her business in order to earn more income. This will enable her to set up a hatchery in the future.

loans.use: To buy chicks

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a 46-year-old married man. He has two children, aged 10 and 17. He has been selling charcoal to earn a living for three years, but was previously employed.
Michael joined a group whose members guarantee each other's loans. He has therefore requested a loan of 20,000 KES to add to his stock of charcoal. Michael hopes to become the major supplier of charcoal in his local community. He describes himself as a focused man.

loans.use: To add to his stock of charcoal

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph D. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 37 years old and single, but still hopes to have his own family someday. To make a living, Joseph owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over 18 years. He says he wants to save for his future family.
Joseph joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Joseph is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and to pay laborers to help prepare his land. This loan will be his fourth from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

About CEVI
Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure, and to pay laborers to prepare his land

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 71-year-old businessman who runs a retail shop.  He sells mainly household items.  In addition, he sells charcoal and paraffin and does farming together with his wife.  He was previously employed and went into business because his salary could not support his big family.  John has managed to educate his eight children and he has only two children who are still in school.  John became a member of Wikwayo Mutituni group in Faulu Kenya.  He has benefited from the group because he can save his money.  He has also taken out a loan of 60,000 KES through the group.  He has requested another loan of 55,000 KES.  He will use the money to purchase charcoal and paraffin.  His dream is to purchase a piece of land for farming to boost his family’s income.  In ten years, he wants to be a wholesaler.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and paraffin

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 52, married and a father of four.  His wife is a farmer and he runs a retail shop.  He also helps his wife in farming.  He was previously employed before he went into business.  He is a member of Ikinya Ria Mbere group in Faulu Kenya where he saves his money.  The members of the group also guarantee each other's loan. Therefore, he has requested 50,000 KES to purchase sugar, maize flour and salt. He dreams of buying a plot in the future. He wants to own a supermarket in ten years.

loans.use: To buy sugar, maize flour and salt

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add cows to increase milk production

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is 34 years old and married with two children who are 12 and 5 years old.  He operates Biz Niz Enterprises where he sells electrical goods.  He has done the business for over ten years.  He gets contracts for wiring in building sites to get more income.  Currently, his major challenge is inadequate stock. Therefore, he has requested a loan of 60,000 KES.  With the loan, he will buy cables, bulb holders, bulbs, sockets, cello tapes and soldering materials.  Peter hopes to become a well-known electrician in the future.  He sees himself being the major supplier of electrical and electronic goods in the future.

loans.use: To buy cables, bulb holders, bulbs, sockets, cello tapes and soldering materials

loans.name: Suren

texts.en: Suren is 51 years old. He lives in Vanadzor city with his wife and two sons. For about 23 years he has been engaged in the flower trading business: he sells bunches and wreaths in a rented place at a large market. Thanks to his business income, he can support his family and also pay for his sons’ education. Suren seeks a 700,000 AMD loan to buy a car, which he will use to transport flowers from Arjut village’s greenhouses to his business place. The car will allow Suren to decrease his business expenses.

loans.use: To buy a car for his flower trading business

loans.name: Sila

texts.en: Sila is 36 years old and married with two children.  He has been selling scrap metals for four years.  He gets his metals from worn out vehicle parts from insurance companies.  He joined Ukweli Baraka group in Faulu Kenya to get financial support.  He has been guaranteed a loan of 20 000 KES by the group.  This will be his first loan and he will use it to purchase more scrap metals.  Sila hopes to provide a quality education to his children in the future.  He dreams of opening other outlets in the future.

loans.use: To buy scrap metals

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Zeynab

texts.en: Zeynab I. is a 40-year-old woman who breeds cattle and raises seasonal fruits and vegetables. Zeynab is married and has four children. She has 15 years of experience in breeding cattle. She buys small calves, raises and fattens them and then sells them for a profit. Her monthly income is 150-200 AZN. She would like to increase the number of cattle she has and for this purpose she applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN.

loans.use: To purchase two cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase medicines for his store

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia A. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 32 years old. Nemia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Nemia owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Nemia is working hard because she wants to give the best to her family. She says she wants to be able to sustain her children's education.

Nemia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nemia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Nemia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Nemia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a member of Baraka Ukweli group in Faulu Kenya.  He joined the group as a businessman who sells second hand shoes.  He has been in the business for five years and he is currently selling shoes at wholesale. This is because he was previously guaranteed a loan of 20,000 KES, which he used to expand the business and successfully repaid.  John is a hardworking man who also sells insurance premiums for tea farmers to supplement his family’s income. He has requested a loan of 40, 000 KES to add more shoes to sell. John hopes to provide a quality education for his child in the future.  In ten years, he wants to own several outlets.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes

loans.name: Mikayil

texts.en: Mikayil A. is a 45-year-old man who sells magazines, newspapers and other office supplies. He is married and has one daughter. Mikayil pays rent for his shop and he wishes one day to have his own shop. His monthly income is 250-350 AZN. He applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN to purchase more books and magazines for his shop.

loans.use: To buy more buy books and magazines to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 46 year old married lady with four children.  She has been practicing dairy farming for twenty years.  She is a member of the Biwanyeji group in Faulu Kenya.  Through the group, she has been able to buy more cows.  She can also afford to pay school fees for her two children who are still in school.  She is requesting a 40, 000 KES loan  to buy a dairy cow and animal feed.  She believes that the loan will help her increase milk production and hence a better income.  She hopes to buy more cows in ten years.  Mary describes herself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and animal feed

loans.name: Akif

texts.en: Akif  S. is a 57 year old man who has been breeding sheep and cattle for the last ten years. Akif is married and has four children. He sells animals to the local butchers and at the livestock bazaar. His monthly profit is 250-350 AZN. He applied for 500 AZN  to purchase three lambs and a calf. He believes this loan will help him to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy three lambs and one calf

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: A. Afi est née en 1954 à Adja dans le Mono au BENIN. Afi est mariée a BOTOKOU Sévérin un commerçant. Le couple a cinq enfants qui sont tous à leur charge. Aucun des enfants n'a fréquenté l'école. C'est depuis dix neuf ans que Afi s'est installée au quartier Cocotomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, où elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Afi vient en aide à son mari et participe avec lui aux différentes charges du ménage. Afi n'a pas aussi fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille, Afi mène comme activité l'élevage de moutons et la vente de plantes médicinales à Cocotomey depuis quatre ans. De façon secondaire Afi vend diverses articles de poteries. Afi s'approvisionne à Dantokpa le marché international du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Afi sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue d'accroître son activité et principalement d'élever le niveau de son activité de vente d'articles de poteries et de plantes médicinales ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Afi A. was born in 1954 in Adja, part of the Mono department of Benin. Afi is married to Sévérin Botokou, a merchant. The couple has five children all under their care. None of the children have attended school. Nineteen years ago Afi settled in the Cocotomey borough of the Abomey Calavi municipality, where she resides with her husband and children. She assists her husband and shares responsibility with him in dealing with the various family expenses. Afi has not attended school either. To meet family needs over the past four years, Avi has been rearing sheep and selling medicinal plants in Cocotomey. As a side business, Afi sells various crockery products. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. This is the second time Afi has requested a credit loan from ALIDé, wanting to expand her activity and in particular increase the sales level for crockery products and medicinal plants. This will enable her to increase customer satisfaction.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 6 dozen canaris (earthenware vessels), 20 bags of leaves and tree bark

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is 30 years old, married and a mother of five.  She does tailoring to earn a living.  She was previously selling second hand clothes for a living.  Being a business-lady, she got involved with the New Jerusalem group in Faulu Kenya.  This has helped her to get new business ideas and to save her money.  Most all, she can easily access loan from Faulu Kenya because the members guarantee each other loans.  

So far, she has managed to service one loan worth 75, 000 KEs which helped her to improve her business.  Therefore, her living standards have really improved.  Currently, he needs 60, 000 KES to buy fabric and an embroidery machine.

loans.use: To buy fabric and an embroidery machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase vegetable seeds for his land

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel N. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 42 years old. Noel is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Noel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Noel has been engaged in his business for over 20 years.

Noel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Noel has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Noel is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure and pay for the laborers who help him prepare his land. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Noel from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure and pay for the laborers who help him prepare his land

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 51 years old. Teresita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Teresita has been engaged in farming for over 25 years. Right now, she also manages a sari-sari store she was able to put up from her income from farming. She says she hopes to expand her store.

Teresita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizer and also additional store inventory. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Teresita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and financially support her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds and fertilizer and also additional store inventory

loans.name: Teresiah

texts.en: Teresiah is 34 years old and married with four children who go to school.  She has been operating a retail shop for five years.  She was introduced to Kanunga Hope group in Faulu Kenya.  She saves her money with the group on a weekly basis.  The members of the group are also responsible for any member who takes out a loan.  She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to add sweets, cooking fat and maize flour to her inventory.  She hopes to buy a plot of land in the future.  In ten years, she wants to have built rental houses.

loans.use: To add sweets, cooking fat and maize flour to her inventory

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Amar

texts.fr: Monsieur  Amar S. est jeune commerçant âgé de 32 a	ns. Il est dans ce domaine depuis 7 ans. Il allait à Bissau en Guinée pour acheter des marchandises pour les revendre à Thiès. En revanche en retournant en Bissau il emportait  des produits qu’il va vendre en Guinée. En d’autre terme il fait de « Import-export informel ». Cependant, il sollicitait un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour compléter son budget d’approvisionnement et préparer son départ en Bissau. Il compte emporter cette fois ci des pièces détachées, poissons fumés et autres…
texts.en:
Mr. Amar S. is a young 32-year-old businessman. He has been in this field for seven years. He goes to Bissau, in Guinea, to buy goods for resale in Thiès. He also brings merchandise with him to Bissau for sale in Guinea. In other words, he practices import-export on an informal level. He is seeking a loan of 100,000FCFA to supplement his stocks and prepare for his next trip to Bissau. He will be taking with him spare parts, smoked fish and other items.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supplement his stocks

loans.name: Matar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Matar H. est un yoffois  de 43 ans qui habite dans le quartier de Mbenguene. Il est marié et père d’un enfant d’un an. 
Monsieur H. a d’abord été pêcheur  avant d’intégrer l’enseignement. De ce fait il est enseignant depuis 1995 et a démarré   par dispenser des cours particuliers. Mais aussi parallèlement  il exerce l’activité de commerce
Monsieur H. est membre de la caisse de Yoff depuis avril 2003.Il a déjà remboursé 5 prêts antérieurs. Il sollicite un  crédit  de 100 000 frs prévu  pour l’achat de divers produits tels que sucre, etc., en provenance de la Gambie et destiné pour son petit commerce durant les vacances. 
La réalisation de bénéfices  qui pourrait découler de cette opération pourrait l’aider a améliorer la situation sociale de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Matar H., 43, is from Yoff and lives in the Mbenguene neighborhood. He is married and the father of a one year old child. Mr. H. was originally a fisherman before going into education. He has been a teacher since 1995 and started off by giving private lessons. At the same time, Mr. H. is involved in commerce and has been a member of the savings institution of Yoff since April 2003. He has already repaid five previous loans. He is asking for a loan of 100,000 francs to buy various products such as sugar, etc., which he obtains in Gambia and sells at his small business during school vacations. The profit that could result from this activity could help him improve the his family's social situation.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en:
Leonard is a 37-year-old married man.  For nine years, he has been operating a retail shop where he sells cereals, mattresses, cooking fat and sugar. That is, he runs a grocery and sells household items.  He joined Kamiti Road group in Faulu Kenya.  In the group, he has learnt how to keep business records.  He has also developed a routine for saving his money on a weekly basis with the group.  

Currently his business has improved through the group and he has managed to employ one person.  He previously took out a loan of 40,000 KES.  With the loan, he was able to boost the business.  His main challenge is lack of capital to add stock so as to meet his customers' demand.  Therefore, he is requesting 80,000 KES to buy cooking fat, mattresses, rice and sugar.  He hopes to expand the business for better output.  In ten years, he wants to own a wholesale shop.  He describes himself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: To buy cooking fat, mattresses, rice and sugar

loans.name: Yakuthon's Group

texts.en:
Yakuthon A. is the leader of the group.  She is 47 and married.  She has raised two sons and a daughter.  The daughter is married and lives separately with her family; the first son works as a butcher and the second son studies at school. In order to make money Yakuthon works as a cook in a kindergarten, and her husband went to work to Russia. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 2000 soms, Yakuthon started to breed livestock and with money received from the loan she wants to purchase four sheep for breeding. In the future she wants to save money to contribute to her son’s wedding expenses.

Galina T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 51 and married. She has two daughters and a son. The daughter works as a cook in a kindergarten, the first son went to work to Russia and the second studies at school. Galina and her husband work in the same kindergarten.  Now she is planning to purchase a pavilion and with money received from the loan she wants to purchase convenience goods in order to resell them in that pavilion. 

Ludmila J., 47, is a widow. She has raised three sons, the first son works as a baker, the second went to work to Russia, and the third son is an auxiliary master. Ludmila applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase building materials to start building their new house. 

Nodirahon H., 26, is married. She has a son who is just two years old.  Seven years ago, with the initial investment of 15,000 soms, Nodirahon and her husband opened their own bakery. They make 18,000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan Nodirahon wants to purchase 20 bags of flour. In the future she plans to expand her business, purchase some land, and build a house for her older brother.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase four sheep

loans.name: Danson

texts.en: Danson is a married man.  He is a young entrepreneur who sells mattresses.  He also operates a grocery store to earn more income. He has been in the business for roughly ten years.  His shop is situated in a populated area.  Therefore, he has good clientele.  He has been able to improve his business through his savings with a group in Faulu Kenya.  He has requested a loan of 80,000 KES.  He will use the loan to add to his stock of mattresses.

loans.use: purchase mattresses for resale

loans.name: Chrispine

texts.en: Chrispine is 26 years old and single.  He sells (mitumba) second-hand clothes to earn a living.  He also sells polythene bags for extra income.  He has been running his business for three years and has employed one person.  Being a member of Blessed group in Faulu Kenya, he has been motivated to work hard in his business.  He also uses his savings with the group to invest in his business.  He has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to add to his clothing stock.  He hopes to expand his shop into a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: To add to his stock of clothes

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys A. O. is a single lady and has three children aged between fourteen years old and seven years old. Her business is located at Anderson Market in Kisumu. She makes clothes at her tailoring shop and sells them to local customers. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Gladys is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more materials for making clothes to grow her business and be able to serve her customers more efficiently. She hopes to expand her business and provide employment to somebody who will be helping her in the business. In future, she sees herself expanding her business and even opening her own boutique. She describes herself as very hardworking.

loans.use: Materials for dress-making

loans.name: Victorine

texts.fr: B. Victorine est née le 23 Mars 1963 et est mariée à FOLLY Jean, un employé des télécommunications. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a environs huit ans que Victorine s'est installée à Cocotomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, avec sa famille. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Victorine a très peu fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Victorine prépare de la nourriture (riz, haricot, pâte de maïs, accompagnés de sauces) qu'elle vend à l'étoile Rouge. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Victorine achète ses produits. Victorine exerce cette activité depuis trois ans et a déjà obtenu deux prêts qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Victorine désire augmenter son stock de produits et augmenter sa production, afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Pour cette raison, Victorine sollicite un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Victorine B. was born on March 23 1963 and is married to Jean Folly, a telecommunications employee. The couple has five children, all of whom have received schooling. About eight years ago, Victorine moved with her family to Cocotomey in the commune of Abomey Calavi. Together, the couple meet the family's various needs. Victorine did not go to school for very long. To meet her needs, Victorine prepares food (rice, beans, corn dough, with sauces) that she sells at the "Etoile Rouge." She purchase her supplies at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Victorine has been involved in this activity for three years and has already obtained two loans which she has fully repaid. To meet the increasing demands of her customers, Victorine would like to increase her inventory, in order to better satisfy her customers. This is why she is asking for a third loan.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 bags of rice, 7 bags of corn, 8 bags of beans, and condiments for sauces.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase different kinds of sanitary products etc. for resale

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl D., 27 years old, is engaged in the fish selling business. Aside from fish, she also sells seashells and has also ventured into a store. The loan which she will receive from Community Economic Ventures Inc. will be used in buying additional merchandise to resell. It will also be utilized in buying more fish and seashells for income.

She said that she likes the CEVI program because aside from loan, she learns a lot from Biblical reflection. She is also proud that she has insurance coverage while a member of CEVI. She likes the way CEVI processes all the loans for borrowers like her.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell and additional store inventory

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana K. E. is married and has five dependents. She has received junior high education.  Nana sells stationery and different types of books at Elmina. She has been in this business for twenty years. Her husband is a librarian.  Nana uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Nana will use the loan to purchase more stationery items to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nana plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more stationery items to resell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
36 years old, Elizabeth S. is a fisherwoman. She is married and has six children. Four of her children go to school. Elizabeth sells fish for a living.
