She started this business as her livelihood 13 years ago and her ambition is to have a sustainable business to help cover the needs of her family. 

She would like to apply for a loan of PhP 4,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy a new boat for her husband. In this way, they will be able to continue earning an income to help pay for the education of their children.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Soliath

texts.fr: A. Soliath est née en 1970 et est mariée à AZILINOU Edouard, un commerçant. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés dont trois sont à leur charge. Soliath vit ensemble avec son mari au quartier Sodjèatinmè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis huit ans. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différents besoins de la famille. Soliath a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire puis a commencé la vente de divers produits (lait, petits pois, mayonnaise, conserve de maïs, riz, couscous, huile végétale, sucre, pâtes alimentaires, savons, papier de toilette, etc.) dans sa boutique située à Saint Michel. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Soliath achète ses produits. Soliath a déjà obtenu auprès de ALIDé, un crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Dans le but d'élever davantage le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Soliath sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Soliath A. was born in 1970. She is married to Edouard AZILINOU, a merchant. The couple has four children, all in school, with three still in their care. Soliath has been living with her husband in the neighborhood of Sodjèatinmè in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, for eight years. The couple provide together for the family’s various needs. After dropping out of high school, Soliath began selling various products (milk, peas, mayonnaise, canned corn, rice, couscous, vegetable oil, sugar, pasta, soap, toilet paper, etc.) in her shop located in St. Michel. She gets her stocks in Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Soliath previously received one loan from ALIDé, which she fully repaid. She is seeking a second loan to further boost her business and better serve her customers.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various products (pasta, rice, canned goods, milk, mayonnaise, sugar, peas, vegetable oil, couscous)

loans.name: Msombo

texts.en: Msombo W. is an entrepreneur and a married woman running a business purchasing and selling different kinds of clothes to customers at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods from the wholesale and retail clothes shops at Kariakoo business shopping center and Karume small entrepreneur used clothes city market. Her business plan is to run a wholesale shop as her business income grows. She needs a loan of T.shs 800,000 to buy more clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Molly

texts.en:
Molly A. O. is twenty-two years old. She is married and has two children aged eight years and four years respectively. Her business is located at a busy business area called Katito in Kisumu. She sells men's clothes, shoes and bags. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge is that some of the items she sells are slow moving therefore reducing profits. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to expand her stock of clothes to grow her business and be able to meet her customers' needs. She hopes to expand her business and even open her own boutique. In future, she sees herself becoming a wholesaler. She describes herself as very hardworking, honest and God-fearing.

loans.use: expand her clothing inventory

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida A. is married to a driver and living with her five dependents. She has no educational background.  Vida sells salted fish and cosmetics at Elmina. She has been trading in this business for eight years now. She uses her income in helping her husband take care of the household. Vida will add her loan to her initial capital to purchase additional cosmetics and salted fish for distribution. She plans to further her children’s education.

loans.use: purchase additional cosmetics and salted fish

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
Epifania V., 50 years old, sells fish for a living. Her husband is a fisherman. They work together to be able to buy their needs. They are childless. Now, they are just focusing on their existing business. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fishing nets and other materials. She said that she likes the services of Community Economic Ventures Inc. She likes it because all of the borrowers have micro-insurance coverage.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Adowa

texts.en: Adowa S. operates a salon at Elmina. Adowa has received senior high education.  She is married and takes care of five dependents. Her husband is a trader. Adowa has been a hairdresser for ten years. With the profit she makes from her salon she helps her husband in providing the needs of her family. Her loan which she hopes to receive will be used to buy more hair creams and other hair products to use on her customers' hair at the salon. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: buy more hair creams and other hair products

loans.name: Carimatou

texts.fr: Née en 1972, A. Carimatou vit depuis une quinzaine d'année à Tanto, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Carimatou est mère de quatre enfants, dont seulement un est encore à sa charge. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Carimatou est une veuve qui vit seule et assure seule ses différentes charges. Carimatou a très peu fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Carimatou vend des produits de soins et de beauté, de même que des divers (sucre, allumettes, etc.) à son domicile. Carimatou achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Carimatou sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et d'accroîre sa clientèle. Le premier crédit dont Carimatou avait bénéficié a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Born in 1972, Carimatou A. has been living for about 15 years in the Tanto district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Carimatou is the mother of four children, of whom only one is still in her care. Some of the children go to school. Carimatou is a widow; she lives on her own and supports herself. She has had very little formal education. In order to provide for her needs, she sells personal care and cosmetic products, as well as other miscellaneous items (sugar, matches, etc), out of her home. Carimatou sells her products in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. This is the second time that Carimatou is seeking a loan from ALIDE in order to expand her business and grow her customer base. Her first loan has been duly repaid.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing personal care products and cosmetics

loans.name: Elimane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Elimane N. est  un  retraité de 67 ans qui vit dans la localité de Yoff dans le quartier de Ngaparou. Il est marié et père de 18 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 6 et 38 ans.
Monsieur N. a pratiqué  l’activité de mécanicien depuis 1964 dans une société de la place connue sous le nom de SAMA ou elle a pris sa retraite depuis 1999. C’est aussitôt qu’il a quitté l’école coranique qu’il a commencé  a apprendre le métier de mécanicien. Son occupation préférée  était  de dépanner les voitures.
Monsieur N. est membre de la caisse de Yoff depuis avril 2007. Il sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu   pour la réfection  de la dalle de l’une des ses chambres qui et en mauvais état.
Son objectif est d’améliorer  le cadre de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Elimane N. is a 67-year-old retiree who lives in the borough of Yoff, in Ngaparou. He is married and a father to 18 children ranging in age from 6 to 38 years old. Mr. N. started working as a mechanic in 1964 at a local company known as SAMA. He retired in 1999. He had started to learn about being a mechanic soon after leaving Koranic school. His favorite pastime was repairing cars. Mr. N. has been a member of the Yoff branch since April 2007. He is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to repair a damaged slab in one of his rooms. His goal is to improve his family’s living environment.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Slab repair

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita C., 39 years old, is a sari-sari storeowner. She is also a fish vendor. She is doing these to be able to buy the needs of their family. She is a widow with four children. 

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to resell. In that way, she will be able to offer her customers more products with variety. She likes the CEVI services because she is also covered by micro-insurance benefits.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dorine

texts.en: Dorine is a married lady with two children aged 1 year old and 5 months.  She has been selling fish for the past three years.  She saves her money with a group in Faulu Kenya on a weekly basis.  Through the group, she previously took out a loan of 40,000 KES which she used to buy more inventory.  She has also learnt new business skills through the group.  She needs to add more stock of fish and fingerlings hence she has requested a loan of 80,000 KES.  Dorine hopes to buy a plot of land in the future.  She describes herself as determined, hardworking, and focused.

loans.use: To add stock of fish and fingerlings

loans.name: Ngwazi

texts.en: Ngwazi A. M. is a smA. business married man running a shop selling clothes at Kigamboni ward. He sells a variety of clothes to customers, both used and new clothes. He purchases his business goods from the wholesale and retail shops at Kariakoo city shopping center and Karume city market. He meets his daily family demands and business capitalization from his business income. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 700,000 to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothesto sell

loans.name: Agathe

texts.fr: Née en 1977, T. Agathe est mariée à ZINSOU Sévérin et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge. Agathe vit depuis dix neuf ans avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Agathe supporte avec son mari les différentes charges du ménage. Pour y arriver, Agathe vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs, riz, haricot et sauce) à la devanture de sa maison. De façon secondaire, Agathe accompagne sa nourriture, des jus de bissap et de citron qu'elle vend à sa clientèle. Agathe exerce cette activité depuis huit ans et a déjà obtenu deux prêts qui ont tous été bien remboursés. La clientèle de Agathe devient de plus en plus grande et Agathe désire augmenter le volume de sa production pour mieux les servir. C'est la raison pour laquelle Agathe sollicite un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1977, Agathe T. is married to Sévérin Zinsou and is the mother of three children, all of whom have been educated. The couple also cares for one other child. For the past nineteen years, Agathe has lived with her husband and children in the Sènadé neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Agathe helps her husband with many household costs. To make ends meet, Agathe sells food (maïze pasta, rice, beans and sauce) from the front of her house. Agathe also sells roselle juice and lemonade to her clients. Agathe has had this business for eight years and has already had two loans that she repaid on time. Agathe has an ever increasing number of clients and she wants to grow her business in order to serve them better. This is why Agathe is seeking her third loan.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy maïze, beans, rice, condiments and charcoal

loans.name: Ma. Lyn

texts.en:
Ma. Lyn M., 29 years old, has been a food vendor for three years. Ma. Lyn is married and has two children. To make a living, Ma. Lyn owns & operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She is seeking funds to help her buy additional merchandise.  She is working very hard to be able to help buy the basic needs of her family.

She needs a loan of PHP 5,000. She will use the loan to buy food ingredients. In that way, she will be able to provide her customers with more food with variety. She said that she likes the services of CEVI. She likes it because she also has micro-insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema M. is a micro-entrepreneur and married woman running a grocery business selling different types of both soft and alcoholic drinks to customers at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods from suppliers at wholesale and at retail. Her business plan is to run a pub as her business income increases. She needs a loan of Tshs 600,000 to buy more drinks to sell.

loans.use: To buy more business goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 2 bags of riz and 3 baskets of condiments.

loans.name: Stanslaus

texts.en: Stanslaus M. O. is 30 years old, single and has no children yet. His business is located at the busy Gorofani estate in Tudor-Mombasa. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well-known for its many, many tourist attraction sites not forgetting the Indian ocean white beaches. He has been selling such items as spinach, kale, tomatoes, carrots and others for the last five years to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenges he has to manage is the high perishability of the vegetables and price fluctuations leading to losses. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more vegetables to grow his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He also hopes to become a landlord someday. He describes himself as very hardworking, customer friendly and honest.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Celestine

texts.en:
Celestine S. is 24 years old. She is single and has no children yet. Her business is located in a busy business area called Mwingi and it is well known by the name of "Miracle Boutique". Mwingi area is served by Thika branch. 

Celestine sells skirts, blouses, trousers and shoes to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to build up her stock of clothes, to grow her business and be able to meet her customers' needs. She hopes to expand her business and build her own premises. In the future, she sees herself as married with a family and a permanent home. She describes herself as very hardworking, persistent and patient.

loans.use: Clothing

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose M. is 21 years old. She is single and does not have any children. Her business is located at mwingi, a business area served by Thika branch. She makes clothes at her tailoring shop and sells them to local customers. She also sells fruits such as bananas in her tailoring shop. She says that this business is profitable and that the only major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of KES 20,000 to buy more materials for making clothes. She hopes to grow her business and be able to serve her customers more efficiently. She also hopes to expand her business and provide employment to someone who can help her in the business. In the future, she sees herself married. She also hopes to build her own home. She describes herself as very hardworking, caring, sociable, and patient.

loans.use: Materials for making clothes

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 32-year-old married man from Lebanon who has two young children. He has eight years of experience working as a farmer. In 2007, he started cultivating his land independently and working on his own. The nature of the ground allows him to grow different varieties of vegetables and fruits according to the different seasons in Lebanon. His business has grown and he has hired a part time worker to help him. He is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work. He estimates that his profit has the potential to increase by 18% after taking the loan. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, in 2003 Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l., a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement to their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase agricultural supplies

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana M. K. sells earthenware bowls and works as a fishmonger in Elmina. Nana has not attained any level of education. She is divorced and has five dependants. Nana has been selling earthenware bowls for some time now. She is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more of her bowls to resell. She hopes to save the new profits from her business to open up an earthenware shop.

loans.use: To buy more earthenware bowls to resell

loans.name: Juan

texts.en: Juan K. is currently in the business of selling textbooks, exercise books, boxes of chalks, pens, etc. She is requesting a loan to stock more textbooks and exercise books to sell. Juan is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a clinical officer. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a pharmacy.

loans.use: Stock more textbooks and exercise books to sell

loans.name: Everine

texts.en: Everine J. is an entrepreneur running a small business selling food to customers in Kigamboni ward, Dar es Salaam. She is a food vendor, preparing both cooked and fried food of different types, and selling soft drinks and "bites" to her customers. She purchases goods from foodstuff shops and the city market. She pays her children's school fees and meets daily family needs from her business income. She needs a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy foodstuff to meet customer demand.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for food preparation

loans.name: Maria Delia

texts.en:
Ma. Delia I.'s  main source of income comes from gathering and selling seaweed at the market. She is from the town of Talibon, Bohol. Maria Delia has spent her whole life growing seaweed to earn an income for her family. She has three children and her ambition is that someday she can send them all to school.

Maria Delia would like to apply for a loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the loan to buy seaweed seedlings and knot that will be used in planting seaweed. What she likes about CEVI's services is that the loan is paid in easy installment terms and the program implementers are very accommodating.

loans.use: To purchase seaweed seedlings

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria S.'s main source of income comes from gathering and selling seaweed at the market. She is 42 years old, married and has nine children. Most of her children go to school. They are from the town of Talibon. Maria works hard to have a stable income that can sustain her family. Maria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Maria is requesting a loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. In addition to credit for its clients, CEVI also provides savings, insurance and training through regular cluster group meetings. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: Madina K. is a married woman running a small business.  She sells fish, both fried and fresh fish, to her customers. She purchases fish from the market at Ferry Fish City Shopping Center in wholesale and retail shops. She also sometimes purchases directly from the fisherman. Her business income is used to meet daily family needs and for business expansion. She needs a loan of 700,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fish for selling

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel K. is 44 years old and married to a hotelier. He has three children aged from six to ten years old. He and his wife hope to give their children a good education to the university level. His business is located at Mwingi, which is served by Thika branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. He has been selling assorted goods, which include handkerchiefs, padlocks, sunglasses, watches, torches, batteries and other items to the local people. He has been doing this business for thirteen years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that there are so many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as his, so customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He will use his loan of Kes 20,000 to increase his stock of assorted items to meet the needs of his customers. He hopes to one day be able to run his business on his own premises. He describes himself as very hardworking, innovative and patient.

loans.use: To buy an assortment of goods for his retail shop.

loans.name: Said

texts.en: Said M. is an entrepreneur who runs a fruit shop in the Mji Mwema and Kigambon wards in Dar es Salaam. He buys and sells a variety of fruit, including pawpaws, oranges, avocados, mangoes, and bananas. He buys the fruit wholesale and sells it retail. He meets his family's needs and his business capital from the business income. He needs a loan of TShs 800,000 to buy more fruit for resale.

loans.use: To buy more fruit for resale.

loans.name: Mwatatu

texts.en: Mwatatu M. S. is a married lady. Her husband is a driver and they have two children aged twelve and nine years old. Her business is located at Mishomoroni estate in Mombasa, a competitive residential area with a ready market. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many, many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean white beaches. She has been operating a restaurant well known as Usicheze Mbali Cafe for the last nine years. Although it is called a cafe, it is actually a restaurant. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is insufficient funds to run the business. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more general items to expand her business. She hopes to expand her business and in the future open a hotel with guest rooms. She describes herself as respectful, honest, and a patient mother.

loans.use: To buy items to expand her business.

loans.name: Bineta

texts.fr:
Madame Bineta G.  est une veuve de 52 ans qui habite  à Ndeugagne à Yoff. Elle est mère de 2 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 21 et 26 ans.
Madame G.  évolue  dans le commerce depuis plus de 40 ans. C’est une activité qu’elle a choisi parce que c’était celle du Prophète  Mohamed  PSL. Et par ce biais son objectif étant de réaliser des bénéfices et de  satisfaire ses besoins personnels  ainsi que ceux de ses enfants, elle s’active dans la vente de beignets et de poissons séchés.
Madame G. est sociétaire  de la caisse de Yoff depuis avril 2009. Elle a déjà bénéficie d’un prêt antérieur. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs qui sera destiné  a l’chat de poissons séchés en Mauritanie. Une partie du financement sera utilisée pour développera  sa vente de beignets.
L’accroissement de ses bénéfices  sera un moyen pour elle de contribuer a l’amélioration  du cadre de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bineta G. is a 52 year old widow who lives in Ndeugagne in Yoff. She is the mother of two children between 21 and 26 years of age. Mrs. G. has more than 40 years experience in business. She chose her business because it was the business of the Prophet Mohammed PSL. She went into the sale of beignets and dried fish and by this means her goal is to make a profit and satisfy her personal needs as well as those of her children. Mrs. G. has been a member of the Yoff credit union since April of 2009. She already received a previous loan. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs which will be used to buy dried fish in Mauritania. One part of the financing will be used to bolster her beignet sales. The growth of her earnings will enable her to contribute to the improvement of her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build her working capital

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard O. O. is a young married man who does not have any children yet. His business is located in Nyalenda, a very busy market in Kisumu. It is well known by the name of "Ring Road Restaurant". He serves food and drinks to the local people. Elderly men from an area in Kisumu called Nyamasaria form most of his clientele. He describes himself as sociable, charismatic and optimistic.

Richard has been in his business for the last two years now and has been able to employ four people. He says that the business is profitable. The major challenge he has is insufficient funds to run the business; however, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more soft drinks to meet his customers' needs. He hopes to expand his business and, in the future, to branch into sugarcane farming.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua K. is a married woman with four children. Her husband is a farmer. She sells bags of charcoal in Elmina. Ekua has received junior high school education. She has been selling charcoal for five years. She helps her husband with the general welfare of their home. Her loan will be used to buy more charcoal for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old single man from Lebanon living with his parents. He has owned a mini market in his town since 2006. With his business income, he helps his father with the family expenses. He took his first loan from Kiva to purchase an accounting system and has been a reliable borrower with on-time repayments throughout his loan cycle. He also decided to repay his full loan amount several months early. He is now asking for a new, larger loan of $2000 to increase his inventory and reinforce his productivity. He is certain that the loan will allow him to expand his business.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been withheld to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support of Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in Lebanese Microfinance since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement to their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: increase his inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 40-year-old married woman from Lebanon. A mother of 5 school-age children, she has established a small clothing shop in her home. She sells women's and children's clothing including lingerie. Her husband is the provider of the family but she supports him with the income she makes. With her US $1000 loan requested from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., she will purchase more merchandise for her business, specifically to increase her selection of women’s and children’s clothes. In the coming year, she expects to increase her profits by 15%. Also, she hopes that she can open a formal store in the future. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been withheld to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en: Ezekiel M. is thirty nine and divorced with two children aged thirteen and ten. He hopes to give his children a good education to the university level. His business is located at Mwingi town — an area served by the Thika Branch. He has been selling shoes to the local people for the last five years. He has employed one person. He says that his business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more shoes to meet his customers' demands. He sees himself as some day having shoe stores in the major towns in Kenya. He describes himself as very responsible, ambitious and social.

loans.use: To buy shoes for his store

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama A. sells palm fruits, onions, fresh peppers and other types of vegetables in Elmina. Ama has been educated up to the junior high school level. She is married with three children. Her husband is a painter. She has been in her trade for three years. She helps supply the basic needs of her family. Her loan will be used to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is of the view that, should there be any form of increase in her business, she will use the revenue to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Onesmus

texts.en: Onesmus M. is 39 years old, married to a teacher and they have four children between the ages of 14 years and 2 years old, whom they hope to give a good education to the university level. His business is located at Mwingi town – a busy area served by the Thika branch. He has been selling books to schools, students, teachers and parents of school-going children. He has been doing this business for four years now and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge is that there are other people doing the same business as him in the area, so customers are spoilt by the choice. He works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more books to meet the demand. He hopes to own a chain of bookshops in major towns. He describes himself as very hardworking, responsible and social.

loans.use: To buy past examination papers

loans.name: Hamad

texts.en: Hamad H. is a married man with a small business. He runs a foodstuff shop in Kitunda ward, Dar es Salaam. He purchases goods from the foodstuff suppliers and from the wholesale shops. The goods he sells include wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, rice, beans, cooking oil and groundnuts. He opened another business selling green vegetables and fruits behind his shop. He meets his family's daily needs and generates capital from his business income. He is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more goods.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Karla Patricia

texts.es: Karla Patricia tiene 41 años, ella tiene 2 hijos que están bajo su cuidado. Ella se dedica a ofrecer el servicio de venta de recarga y frijoles. Por lo que tiene más de 5 años, ya que anteriormente había realizado un financiamiento porque le permitió tener un capital de trabajo adicional, con lo que compró de contado de esta manera sus ganancias aumentaron y logró beneficiar más a su hogar.es por eso que solicita este financiamiento para la compra de recarga y frijoles que es lo que más solicitan sus clientes. Siempre está pensando en obtener otro medio de ingreso como es una pulpería.
texts.en:
Karla Patricia is 41 years old, and she has two children under her care. She sells phone card recharging services and beans. She has been in this line of work for five years. She had a previous loan, which allowed her to have additional working capital. She used it to buy for cash. That way her earnings increased and helped her household more. She is requesting a loan to buy phone card recharges and beans. Her customers request these items the most. She is always thinking of another way to get income like a general store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is currently in the business of selling bread, fried fish and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions and cooking oil to sell. She is 24 years old and married to a businessman. She has no children yet. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a rental house.

loans.use: To stock onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 48 years old. She is married and has been blessed with six children with ages ranging between 10 and 30. Three of the children are attending school. Rosemary has been farming for the last five years on the outskirts of Kitale town in Western Kenya. Her farm produces maize, beans and eggs which she sells at the local market. She is also a food vendor. She says that she faces the challenge of poultry diseases and so far there is no insurance coverage for the poultry trade.

Rosemary has requested a loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her poultry project. This being her fourth loan from Juhudi, she is optimistic that her income will increase and that she will be able to pay for the education of her children. She hopes that the business will have expanded in five years' time and she will be reaping the full benefits of the project.

loans.use: To expand her poultry project

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in Western Kenya. She has been operating her mixed farm for seven years and has employed one farmhand. Her farm produces sorghum, milk, maize, tea and beans, which she sells to the local market. She also operates a shop where she makes at least 25,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month.

Jackline is 48 years old. She is married and has four children between the ages of 13 and 6. Two of the children are currently in school.

Jackline has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 70,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. She says that the extra income from this loan will enable her to expand her shop and improve the living standards of her family.

However, she however faces the challenges of poor weather conditions, the high cost of fertilizers, and diseases that affect her crops and animals.

In the future, she would like to expand her farm by purchasing more dairy cows. She says that if you are well prepared, then you can do a lot with the money from Juhudi.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Alassane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alassane S. habite à Yoff Ndenatte. Il est âgé  de 47 ans. Il est marié et père de 2 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 2 et 4 ans. 
Monsieur S. a choisi l’activité de commerce par passion. Etant donné qu’il vit dans un village ou la pêche  occupe une importante place  il a préféré orienter son commerce vers les matériels  de pêche. Ainsi  il pratique cette activité depuis  qu’il a terminé  ses études primaires.
Monsieur S. est membre de la caisse de Yoff depuis avril 2009.Il a déjà  remboursé un crédit antérieur. Il sollicite un crédit de 200 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de matériels de pêche  tels que filets, hameçons, autres   qui seront destinés a ala vente.
Monsieur S. souhaite améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille a travers l’accroissement de ses bénéfices.
texts.en:
Mr. Alassane S. lives in Yoff Ndenatte. He is 47 years old, married and the father of 2 children between the ages of 2 and 4. Passion led Mr. S. in his choice of business. Given that he lives in a village where fishing occupies an important place, he preferred to go into the business of selling fishing gear. Thus, he has operated this business since he finished elementary school. Mr. S. has been a member of the Yoff credit union since April of 2009 and has already paid back a previous loan. He is requesting a loan of 200,000 francs intended for the purchase of fishing gear such as nets, hooks, and other items to be put up for sale. Mr. S. wants to improve the living conditions of his familly through the growth of his earnings.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 48 years old. He is married and has seven children with ages ranging between 2 and 14. All the children attend school. He is a farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for eight years and has employed one farmhand. His main products are milk and tea, which he sells to Kenya Cooperative Creameries and a local tea factory respectively.

William has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase a dairy cow. This being his third loan, he says that it will increase his milk production and earn him more income. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children and uplift their living standards.

William says that his major challenges have been diseases and an unreliable market for his products. He hopes, however, that in five years' time, he will have acquired more dairy cows and built a modern dairy unit.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en:
Zipporah is 63 years old. She is a widowed mother of three children between the ages of 37 and 41. She has been farming for the last 10 years in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya. Her farm produces beans, maize, vegetables and milk, which she sells to the local market. She has employed two people from her community to help with the farm work.

Zipporah recently completed her previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) and has requested this loan of 50,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. She says that this loan will increase the income of the family and they will also be able to acquire another asset that will be used as security to apply for more loans in future.

Her biggest challenge has been lack of enough land to graze and a lack of knowledge on animal husbandry. She hopes, however, to improve her dairy farming to a more productive business by buying good quality dairy cows.

She is grateful to Juhudi for their constant support and will request more loans once she has completed this loan.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Jenipher Olanga

texts.en:
Jenipher could hardly bear the economic hurdles her family was experiencing since affording even a single meal was a hard task due to the fact that she was separated from her husband and had to single-handedly fend for the family's needs. In the year 2003, she started a hotel business (a very primitive restaurant) in Nyamasaria market to generate income for the family's upkeep. 

She normally travels after every three days to bring in more stock. Her main reason for joining K-MET was to get a loan worth 20,000 Kenyan shillings, which she will use part of to expand her business and will then channel some into paying college fees for her son. 

She is aged 45 years and a mother of five children.

loans.use: Expand business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Simion

texts.en:
Simion is a member of the Kondamet Group, which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. He has been operating his farm in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya for the last 10 years. He has employed two people from his community. He sells his maize, tea, vegetables and milk to the local market.

His biggest challenges have been diseases that affect his production, lack of enough knowledge on disease and pest control, and unstable prices for his products.

Simion has requested this loan from Juhudi of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase a dairy cow. He says that this loan will increase his income and enable him to pay school fees for his children. In the future, he intends to improve his dairy farming by building a dairy unit and buying quality dairy cows.

He is grateful to Juhudi and its partners for their constant support and pledges to complete this loan so as to get more loans in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Agnès

texts.fr: K. D. Agnès est née en 1956 et est mariée à AWISSOU Etienne, un jardinier. Le couple a quatre enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Il y a environs cinq ans que la famille habite Cocotomey dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Agnès subvient ensemble avec son mari aux besoins de la famille grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. N'ayant pas fréquenté l'école, Agnès vend des friperies et des éponges de toilette de façon ambulante, ce qui lui permet de faire face à ses besoins. Agnès achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Agnès exerce cette activité depuis quatre ans et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Dans le but d'agrandir son activité et d'accroître sa clientèle, Agnès sollicite un autre crédit afin de se faire plus de revenu.
texts.en:
Agnès K. D. was born in 1956 and is married to Etienne Awissou, a gardener. The couple have four children, some of whom are in school. The family have lived for about five years in Cocotomey in the community of Abomey Calavi. Together with her husband, Agnès helps pays the family expenses thanks to her business income. Not having gone to school, she sells secondhand clothing and cosmetic sponges on foot, which allows her to meet her needs. Agnès buys her products in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been engaged in this business for the last four years and has already obtained two loans through ALIDé, both of which she has repaid in full. With the goal of growing her business and gaining more customers, Agnès is requesting another loan to increase her income.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a bale of secondhand clothing.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a farmer from the town of Kitale in Western Kenya. She has been operating her mixed farm for the last eight years. Her farm produces vegetables and potatoes, which she sells to the local market. She also owns some rental houses in the same area.

Susan is 37 years old. She is married and has five children between the ages of 3 and 16. Three of the children are currently attending school.

Susan has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 31,200 Kenyan shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that this loan will improve her life as a farmer by enabling her to expand her farming and her family will live a better life since they will have enough milk for consumption and sale.

She says that in the next five years, she wishes to have three dairy cows and supply milk to the local market and Kenya Cooperative Creameries. She appreciates this loan and plans to get more loans from Juhudi.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Margaret Nancy

texts.en:
Margaret Nancy A. is 39 years old and a happily married woman. She has three children whom she is assisting her husband in taking care of. Previously, she used to operate a fishing boat business but due to its demands in terms of time commitment, she decided to quit and start a new venture with a 14-seat passenger service vehicle in the year 2009. 

Due to the business’ legal requirements, she has applied for a loan worth 30,000 Kenyan shillings to settle the log-book issue of her vehicle so that it can start its operation and generate income. Her future plan is to buy another passenger-service vehicle to broaden her income base and improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To settle log book issues

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 44 years old. He is married and has no children. He is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. He has been operating his mixed farm for the last 20 years and has employed one farmhand. His farm produces eggs, maize, milk and beans, which he sells to the local market. His biggest challenge has been diseases that are rampant and lead him to incur losses.

Francis has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to expand his poultry project. He says that this loan will increase his income from the sale of eggs and this will improve the lives of his family.

In five years time, he hopes to have increased the number of his poultry that will increase his income. He is grateful to Juhudi for empowering him economically.

loans.use: To expand his poultry project

loans.name: Dorreny

texts.en:
Dorreny is 28 years old. She is married and has been blessed with five children with ages ranging between 3 and 11. Four of the children are currently attending school. 

She has been farming for the last three years in the town of Kitale in Western Kenya. Her products are maize and beans, which she sells to the local market.

Dorreny has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 31,200 Kenyan shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that this loan will help her acquire a productive asset and will enable the family to get their basic needs. She faces, however, the challenges of diseases that attack her cows and lack of enough animal feed.

In five years time, she wishes to have two more dairy cows and five dairy goats.

She is very happy with the loans she got from Juhudi because they have enabled her to be a dairy farmer and she promises to pay well and get another loan for more development.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bessy Auma

texts.en:
After the completion of her education, Bessy started a clothes-selling business in the year 2000 in the Ahero market to generate income to enhance self-reliance. She normally travels after every two months to Nairobi to purchase more stock. 

Being a community health worker, she came to realize about the KMET-Kiva microfinance initiative and decided to request a loan worth 50,000 Kenyan shillings to enable her to boost her business and get a substantial income, which will later enable her to buy a plot to build both her residence and rental houses. 

She is 28 years of age and a married mother of three children. She lives in Rabuor in Kisumu.

loans.use: To boost business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To establish a poutry farm

loans.name: Jeanne Mindécè

texts.fr: A. Jeanne Mindécè est née le 07 Février 1961 à Athiémé dans le département du Mono au Bénin. Mariée à DEGBE Antoine, Jeanne est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Jeanne vit ensemble avec sa famille à Cocotomey, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi, depuis huit ans. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins du ménage. Jeanne a très peu fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Jeanne mène comme activité la vente de maïs et de façon secondaire la vente de charbon de bois. Jeanne exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et a obtenu antérieurement deux crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. La demande en maïs et en charbon de bois de Jeanne ne cesse d'augmenter et donc pour répondre à toute sa clientèle, Jeanne sollicite un troisième prêt pour rehausser le niveau de son activité.
texts.en:
Jeanne Mindécè A. was born on February 7, 1961 at Athiémé in the Mono department of Bénin. Married to Antoine DEGBE, Jeanne is the mother of six children, all of whom have attended school. For eight years, Jeanne has lived with her family at Cocotomey, in the Abomey Calavi commune. Together the couple provides for the household needs. Jeanne has very little formal education. In order to provide for her needs and those of her children, she has a business selling corn and a side business selling charcoal. Jeanne has operated this business for five years and previously obtained two loans that she fully repaid. Her customer demand for corn and charcoal continues to increase and in order to meet all this demand, Jeanne is requesting a third loan to build up the level of her business.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 3 sacks of corn and 7 bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher has been operating his mixed farm for the last eight years in Kitale town, Western Kenya. He sells his milk, vegetables and fruits to the local market. He also operates a hotel (restaurant) in the same area.

Christopher is 59 years old. He is married and has 11 children between the ages of 10 and 29. Seven of the children are attending school.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 31,200 Kenyan shillings to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This being his second dairy loan from Juhudi, he believes that his milk production will improve and this will earn him more income. He faces, however, the challenge of transportation of milk to the market and diseases that attack his dairy cows.

He says that in the next five years, he wishes to have three dairy cows and be the main milk supplier to the local market. He says that the loans he has been given have enabled him to acquire productive assets that he would not be able to acquire alone.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther L. is a business lady who has been a fish vendor since 2006. Before this she had a tailoring business but the returns were not enough to enable her to effectively support her husband in taking care of the family. Today, Esther can testify to how lucrative fish selling can be if you commit and dedicate yourself to it. Her aim of diversifying it has been a great challenge since she lacks enough capital. After having been trained by K-MET as a community health worker, she realized how impressive the initiative of a revolving loan fund was, and requested a loan worth Kshs.50000 to help her in improving her business. She goes to Kisumu town every day for additional stocks. She is 28 years of age, married, and the proud mother of two children who stay in Kisumu town.

loans.use: To boost business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Alinnson Rafael

texts.es: Alinsson Rafael Guerreo Pérez tiene 32 años,  vive con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 6 meses y 10 años respectivamente, en la zona comercial del barrio Ciudadela 20 de Julio, al sur de Barranquilla, donde tiene un negocio de venta de drogas medicinales, que inició en el año 2000 cuando se inició como negociante distribuyendo queso y algunas variedades de mercancías; desde que hace 4 años está vinculada a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, organización que en un principio la apoyó con crédito para vender queso y mercancías por encargo, ahora ya tiene un negocio de mayor tamaño en su infraestructura y en sus clientela y ha diversificado la oferta vendiendo droguería medicinal, genera dos empleos y se sostiene aunque tenga una competencia muy fuerte, porque sus precios son mejores que los de sus competidores, porque compra al por mayor y sabe donde hacerlo; su trabajo lo realiza desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche todos los días,  ya sus clientes conocen su ritmo  por eso siempre lo buscan  y le refieren otros. Alinsson ha recibido 8 créditos y con su credikiva completa el noveno con el que comprará medicamentos genéricos y comerciales para surtir su pequeña farmacia. Está muy satisfecho con su negocio y con el apoyo institucional recibido porque su nivel de vida ha mejorado, pero aun sueña con tener una  casa propia  y convertir su pequeño negocio en una gran droguería y este su mayor desafío para lograr un futuro mejor para su familia.
texts.en:
Alinsson is 32 years old and lives with his wife and their 2 children, aged 6 months and 10 years respectively, in the commercial zone of the Ciudadela 20 de Julio barrio, south of Barranquilla. He has a medicinal drug store there that he opened in 2000, the year he began his business career by distributing cheese and some varieties of merchandise. For the last 4 years he has been involved with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, an organization that helped him initially with loans to sell cheese and merchandise on order. Now he has a larger business in both infrastructure and clientèle, and he has diversified his offerings, selling medicinal drugs. Alinnson has 2 employees and he sustains his business, despite fierce competition, with lower prices than competitors, because he buys at wholesale and knows where to purchase. Alinnson works from 8:00am until 9:00pm every day. Now his customers know his schedule and they seek him out and refer him to others. Alinnson has received 8 loans and this loan request from Kiva will be his 9th. He will buy generic and commercial medicines to resupply his little pharmacy. Alinnson is very satisfied with his business and with the institutional help he has received and his level of living has improved. But he still dreams of having his own house and converting his small business into a large drug store, and this is his major challenge to accomplish a better future for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING GENERIC AND COMMERCIAL MEDICINES TO SUPPLY HIS SMALL PHARMACY

loans.name: Godwinodhiambo

texts.en: Godwin Odhiambo O. is 29 year old and lives in Kisumu. He operates a poultry business in Jubilee market which he started in 2000. Initially he was employed but the salary could not adequately meet the rising needs of his family. He travels to Ahero and Sondu markets to enable him meet the ever increasing demand for poultry in Kisumu town. Godwin hopes that if his loan request of Kshs.30000 is responded to, he will be able to uplift his business and achieve his life dream of setting up residential and rental houses and also to afford a quality education for his children. He is married and the happy father of three children.

loans.use: To boost business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Cécile

texts.fr: A. Cécile est née le 01 janvier 1958 au Bénin. Mariée à HOUSSOU Samuel un boulanger le couple a six enfants à charge tous scolarisés. Cécile n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. La famille vit depuis près de vingt cinq ans au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou capitale économique du Bénin. Cécile aide son mari à supporter les charges de la famille. Pour y arriver, Cécile mène comme activité la vente d'oranges et comme activité secondaire la vente de pain à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et aussi à son domicile depuis une dizaine d'année. Cécile a déjà bénéficié cinq fois de crédits auprès de ALIDé avec un bon remboursement. C'est dans le but d'accroître son activité et pour satisfaire sa clientèle que Cécile demande encore auprès de ALIDé un autre concours financier.
texts.en:
Cécile A. was born January 1, 1958, in Bénin. She is married to Samuel Houssou, who is a baker. They have six dependent children, all of whom have been to school. Cécile herself never went to school. For 25 years, the family has lived in the Sènadé neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. Together, Cécile and her husband cover the family's expenses. To play her part, for about ten years Cécile has had a business selling oranges and bread at Dantokpa, Benin's international trade center and from her home. She has repaid five previous loans from ALIDé. To grow her business and meet customer demand, she is once more asking ALIDé for a loan.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy oranges and bread

loans.name: G.s. El Arca De Noe Ii Group

texts.es: Petrona y Maria Gerarda son el Grupo Solidario Arca De Noé II. Ambas se dedican a la venta de granos básicos. Este no es el primer financiamiento que realizan juntas, por lo que siempre están buscando la forma de generar ingresos. Maria Gerarda se dedica a la venta de granos básicos, las dos son personas responsables que siempre están pendientes de mejorar sus negocio, la mayoría de sus clientes asisten a su local, ya que la atención tan esmerada que ofrece es lo que la caracteriza con sus clientes. Así con este crédito podrán realizar las compras de materia prima necesaria.
texts.en:
Petrona and Maria make up the communal bank "Arca De Noé II" and both make a living selling basic grains. This is not the first time they have taken out a loan together, for they are always looking for ways to generate income. Maria Gerarda sells basic grains. Both women are responsible people who are always looking to improve their business. Most of their customers come to them because of the careful attention they provide; this is what attracts their customers. They will be able to buy raw materials with this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ruth Atieno

texts.en:
Ruth Atieno O. sells chapattis (an unleavened flatbread) and mandazis (a donut-like pastry) in Nyamasaria, a business she started in 2000 to generate income and help her husband in supporting their family. She travels on a weekly basis to Kibuye market to purchase her stock and would like to obtain a loan of Ksh 10,000 so as to improve her business and be able to generate more income. This will help her save some that she will then use to buy a piece of land and build rental houses.

Ruth is 32 years old, is married, and is the mother of three children.

loans.use: To add stock to improve her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Olga Del Socorro

texts.es:
Olga S. A. tiene 3 hijos en las edades de 19 a 25 años y vive en el barrio el Carmen de la ciudad de Barranquilla. Ella inició su negocio  de preparación y venta de alimentos, hace alrededor de 15 años cuando, como dice ella,  se le dio por vender cervezas comidas rápidas y sancochos los fines de semana. Gradualmente su clientela creció y con cada préstamo realizado por la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, organización en la que tiene 10 años de estar vinculada, ha logrado vender diariamente almuerzos, que es su mayor mercado y ha dejado las comidas rápidas para los fines de semanas, porque  las familias aumentan sus compras en  los deliciosos perros calientes, sanduches, hamburguesas,  porque dejan de cocinar  los fines de semanas para descansar. También  desde que recibió sus créditos con esta organización,  ha dejado de prestar dinero a intereses muy altos y obtiene mayor utilidad con la venta de sus productos, porque comprar al por mayor le significa ahorro en el precio de los materias primas e insumos,  que ella requiere para realizar su trabajo.
Su meta siguiente y también su mayor desafío es comprar su casa, para eso se prepara ahorrando la cuota inicial,  para acceder al megaproyecto institucional Villas de San Pablo en Barranquilla, donde la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  juega un papel importante en la construcción de comunidades. Otra de sus metas es que su hijo termine sus estudios, porque sueña con que él sea exitoso. 
Olga S. últimamente ha presentado problemas con su estufa, porque se encuentra en mal estado y demora los tiempos de cocción, además de agotarse más,  por eso, para ella obtener un credikiva es la mejor solución, con él comprará  una estufa semiindustrial utensilios y el resto lo invertirá  en  materia prima e insumos
texts.en:
Olga S. A. has 3 children between the ages of 19 and 25 and she lives in the neighborhood of el Carmen in the city of Barranquilla. She began her food service business about 15 years ago when, as she says, she began to sell beer and fast foods and soups during the weekends. Gradually her clientele grew and with each loan from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, an organization she's been involved with for 10 years, she's managed to sell lunch daily, which is her biggest market. She's left the fast foods for the weekends because families increase their purchases with delicious hot dogs, sandwiches, and hamburgers because they relax on weekends instead of cooking. Since she's received the loans from this organization she's stopped borrowing money with high interest rates and her sales have improved because buying wholesale has saved her money on primary materials that she needs to do her work. Her next goal and also her biggest challenge is buying her house. For this purpose she's preparing to save the initial cost to gain access to the institutional mega project Villas de San Pablo en Barranquilla, where the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo plays an important role in the construction of communities. Another of her goals is that her son finishes his studies because she dreams that he'll be successful. Olga S. has recently had problems with her stove because it's in bad condition and it delays cooking times, in addition to just being worn out. This is why, for her, obtaining a loan from Kiva is the best solution. With the loan she'll buy a semi-industrial stove and utensils, and with the rest she'll invest in primary materials and ingredients.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of semi-industrial stove and utensils; the rest will be used to buy primary materials and ingredients

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en: For the past ten years, Oscar has been in the cleaning business for commercial and residential buildings. Three years ago, with the help of his wife, he decided to start his own business. He now provides maintenance, upkeep, and car-wash services to the buildings where he works. Oscar loves being his own boss because it has given him a new freedom. He is passionate about the business and is able to send his daughters to university. He is confident that starting his own business has created a better future for his family. Oscar’s first loan with ACCION USA allowed him to buy equipment for his new car-wash service. Now he will use his second loan to buy lists of clients and expand his advertising capabilities. This will allow him to reach out to clients in the greater Miami area. With a great attitude and many client referrals, Oscar is happy to report that his business is constantly growing. He strives to provide excellent services to his clients, which they expect of him. Oscar is grateful for ACCION USA’s confidence in his business and is looking forward to taking on new residential and commercial buildings as customers. About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA: Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education. Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To buy lists of clients, expand his advertising capabilities and create a website

loans.name: Nkwain

texts.en:
Nkwain L. B. is a married mother of six currently living in Baingo, Cameroon. She has been with GHAPE since 2009 and has demonstrated a creditworthy character exemplified by her repayments, consistent attendance at meetings and support of her borrowing group. She is now requesting a second loan from GHAPE of 95,000 CFA in order to purchase seven tins of beans, four tins of soya bean, dry fish, soap and one hundred liters of palm oil. With this latest loan, Nkwain will continue the business practices supported by her prior loan. As she has been successful in her business for over ten years, she believes it will continue to prosper.

Nkwain hopes to use the profits from her business to continue reinvesting in her business, purchase kitchen utensils, pay for her children’s textbooks and meet her GHAPE obligations. Her biggest struggle has been with the passing of her son. It is a burden she lives with everyday. She will therefore do whatever is necessary to ensure her children stay healthy and safe.

Nkwain’s loan would be provided by the The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business and financial management, basic health maintenance, life skills and family values. Clients are also required to deposit a small amount of money into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community among its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase beans, dry fish, soap and palm oil for resale

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is married with four children and all her children go school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. A few months ago she changed her business enterprise from selling bananas to chickens and now she sells chicken from the very stall where she was selling bananas. She buys her chickens from areas of Kawempe, Kyebando, Kanyanya and Ntinda. She wants to use this loan to buy more chickens for resale.

Florence works seven days a week. Her business challenges include the transport of chickens, thieves and seasonality. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and start rearing chickens herself and also to buy a plot of land and build her own rental rooms. Florence decided to work with MCDT SACCO because of the low interest rate charged. She resides in and owns a five-room house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Luis Hernan

texts.es:
Luis Hernán Agatan se dedica al diseño y fabricación de Joyas para matrimonios, anillos de grado y de compromisos. El vive en el Noroccidente de Bogotá, está casado y tiene y tiene 2 hijos de 3 y 11 años, a los que espera llevarlos a que sean exitosos.
Luis Hernán está vinculado a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo desde el año 2002, su actividad principal se basa en el diseño, arreglo y reparación de joyas de oro y plata que vende por encargo a familiares, amigos y referidos.
Lleva 13  años de experiencia en el negocio, el cual trabaja en su propia casa;   con cuatro créditos con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo durante 8 años  ha logrado, aumentar su producción, diversificar su oferta y comprar herramientas necesarias para el desarrollo de este oficio.
Su sueño es proyectar su mercado objetivo a los colegios para   fabricar los anillos de grado a sus estudiantes, que termines la educación secundaria, mediante convenios con sus directivos y por otro lado ampliar su taller que cada día crece en producción y en servicios oportunos. En la actualidad solicita su Credikiva que invertirá en la compra de materias primas e insumos para la elaboración y reparación de joyas de oro y plata
texts.en:
Luis Hernán Agatan designs and makes jewelry for weddings, school rings, and engagements. He lives in the northwest part of Bogota, and is married with 2 children. His children are 3 and 11 years old, and he hopes to help them to become successful. Luis Hernan has been involved with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo since 2002. His main activity is the design and repair of gold and silver jewelry that he sells through orders to friends, acquaintances and people referred to him. He has 13 years of experience in this business, and he does the work in his own home. With 4 loans from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo over the last 8 years, he has managed to increase his production, diversify his offerings and buy the tools he needs to develop in this line of work. His dream is to target the school market, making school rings for students who are finishing their secondary education, through contracts with the school directors, and also to expand his workshop that grows every day in its production and timely services. He is now requesting a loan from Kiva that he will invest in the purchase of raw materials and supplies to make and repair gold and silver jewelry.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase raw materials and supplies to make and repair gold and silver jewelry

loans.name: G.s. Los Coquitos Group

texts.es: El Grupo Solidario Los Coquitos está conformado por Mayra Modesta y Paz Catalina. Paz Catalina tiene 67 años. La actividad económica es de brindar el servicio de Nintendo, anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de leña y con el tiempo obtuvo algo de ganancia compro ropa usada la cual distribuía comarca. Posteriormente con las ganancias que recibía de ahorro logro iniciar el servicio de nintendo. Mayra Modesta tiene la edad de 37 años. Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa nueva y usada. Este negocio surgió por idea propia y realmente se dio cuenta de que rápidamente almacenó algunos ingresos. Juntas quieres realizar un financiamiento para incrementar sus inventarios en los artículos necesarios.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Los Coquitos is made up of Mayra Modesta y Paz Catalina. Paz Catalina is 67 years old. Her economic activity is a Nintendo video game service. Before this she sold firewood and in time, with the income from that, she bought used clothing which she resold in the area. After this, with the savings that she was able to accumulate, she started this Nintendo service. Mayra Modesta is 37 years old. She sells used and new clothing. This business was her own idea and she noticed that she rapidly made some income. They are requesting a loan together to be able to increase their respective inventories.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ngombol1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité NGOMBOL 1 est créé le 28 décembre 2009. Il fait partie du Banc Villageois de THIEO. Il est composé de 14 femmes issues du même village.

Mariama C., (la femme qui lève la main debout en deuxième position à partir de la gauche) est présidente du groupe. Elle est âgée de 35 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants en charge. 

Elle fait un petit commerce de lait caillé. Elle achète du lait frais de vache, le fait cailler et le vende en faisant du porte à porte. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de 5 ans.
Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter périodiquement 40 seaux de lait.

Avec les bénéfices qu’elle réalise à partir de son activité elle participe à la prise en charge la famille en achetant des provisions pour la nourriture.
texts.en:
Solidarity group NGOMBOL 1 was created on December 28, 2009. It's part of the "Banc Villageois de THIEO". It is composed of 14 women, all from the same village. Mrs. C. (second women from the left on the back in the picture, raising her hand) is the group's president. She's 35 years old, married, and the mother of 3 children she has to support. She has a small business selling yogurt. She buys fresh cow milk, turns it into yogurt, and sells it door to door. She's been running this business for five years. Her new loan will enable her to buy 40 buckets of milk on a regular basis. With the profits drawn her business, she helps to support her family by purchasing food.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 40 buckets of fresh cow milk

loans.name: Tuwisana Plus Group

texts.en:
Papy K., a 31-year-old married man, has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2007. He is the leader of the community bank named Tuwisana Plus that is composed of 22 members united in solidarity with the goal of developing their businesses through loans from HOPE DRC, a partner of HOPE International.

Papy operates a general store in southwest Kinshasa, earning $30 a week. He has acquired solid experience and contacts and maintained good management skills. Papy works hard, hoping to realize his dream of one day achieving financial independence and opening a large store in his neighborhood.

Papy is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE DRC, having five times obtained and correctly repaying loans. With his next loan he will increase his stock of merchandise by buying canned goods, milk, and sacks of rice and sugar and reselling them at a profit.

loans.use: To buy canned goods, milk, and sacks of rice and sugar for resale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mbighamen

texts.en:
Mbighamen A. is a married father of two who currently lives in Chuaku, Belo-Cameroon. A. is currently requesting a third loan from GHAPE. He has been with GHAPE since 2008, and he has demonstrated a creditworthy character exemplified by his repayments, consistent attendance at meetings, and support of his borrowing group.

With this latest loan, A. is hoping to continue the business practices supported by his prior loans. He has requested 340,000 XAF in order to purchase seven female goats for 100,000 XAF, 150 chicks for 150,000 XAF, fowl feed for 50,000 XAF, and seedlings for 40,000 XAF. He believes that this business will succeed, because there is a ready market for his product. He hopes to use the profits from his business to build his home, to purchase more land, and to pay his children's school fees. He hopes to improve his children's living conditions in order to avoid the hardships that he has dealt with throughout his life-- struggles such as a lack of education, illnesses, and unemployment.

A.'s loan would be provided through the Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE), a non-profit nongovernmental organization based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and the alleviation of poverty through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase goats, chicks, fowl feed, and seedlings

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married with seven children, of whom five go to school and the eldest two are working. Currently, she is not taking care of any additional family members.
