Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Ny Sok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny S. is the village bank president. She is 35 years old and was selected by thirteen people located in Damnak Reachea village, Takeo province. All the members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their businesses. Mrs. Ny S. is a farmer who owns a 1.5 hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. She is a dessert seller while her husband, Mr. Nuch Vech, is a construction worker.

Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Ny S. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of three children of whom all are studying in school and they are helping with their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Neang Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Damnak ReaC. village, fourteen people make up this village bank loan. They have selected Mrs. Mom N., who is 41 years old, to be village bank president. They will use their portions of the loan in various ways to improve their businesses. Mrs. Mom N. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land for cultivating rice to sell to support her family, while her husband, Mr. Chem Ban, is a laborer. Although they do try to work a lot, they are only able to earn a little money. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Mom N. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is the mother of a child who is twenty-one years old.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Mrs. Aun Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en: Sixteen villagers from Thommoda village I. Takeo province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Aun P., born I. 1979, is a village bank president who was selected by the other members who will also be using portions of the loan. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating rice to sell to support her family, while her husband, Mr. Yoeurn Yorn, is a palm-juice collector who sells sugar palm to support his family, and he is also a construction worker. They try to work a lot, but they can only earn a small income. So, to increase her family's income, Mrs. Aun P. is seeking a loan to buy two piglets for breeding and pig food to start a new business, and with the rest of the loan she will purchase fertilizer. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a laborer, while the others are enrolled I. a local school and are helping their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy two piglets for breeding and pig food

loans.name: Mr. Moeun Min Village Bank Group

texts.en: Seventeen people in Thommoda village, Takeo province, make up this village bank loan. They will use their portions of the loan in different ways to support their businesses. Mr. Moeun M., who is 50 years old, is the village bank president selected by the other members. He is a palm-juice collector who makes palm sugar and is also a musician, while his wife, Mrs. Rat Ngem, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land with which she is able to earn good money to support her family. Although they try to work hard, they can only earn a little money. So to improve his family's living conditions, Mr. Moeun Mi is asking for a loan to buy some piglets, pig food, and chicken food. He is the father of a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy some piglets, pig food, and chicken food

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fabrics

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia is married with four children who all go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She rents and lives in a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and food.
Jalia owns a stall in Owino market selling second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for eight years and works six days a week. She sells, both retail and wholesale, to all categories of people. Jalia buys clothes from the very market where she works and so doesn’t pay transportation costs. Her main business challenge is seasonality because when it rains she has few customers. In the future, she hopes to see her business grow larger and start importing clothes herself. She also wants to buy her own plot of land. Jalia decided to join Kiva partner, MCDT, because she wanted additional capital. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. In addition to her clothing business, she also earns money from a motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Naira

texts.en: Naira M. is married with one child and expecting a second child soon. Naira has been successfully managing a bakery since 2009. She makes local Armenian bread that is so popular it is being sold out straight from the bakery. Naira’s husband helps his wife in the business a lot. Their bread started to be in demand from shops that require delivery. With the help of this loan, Naira is planning to buy a car to deliver the bread to the shops and thus increase her family business.

loans.use: To buy a car for bread delivery

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en: Ruben Y. is a 26-year-old man who takes care of his parents who are pensioners. Ruben has been in business since 2007 – he rents a trading booth in a marketplace from where he sells women’s clothing. With the help of this loan, Ruben is planning to buy more clothing for his customers.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for his customers

loans.name: Determiners Group

texts.en:
Samuel G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Determiners.

He is 33 years old, married and has four children who are between 6 to 14 years old. He was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to lack of financial support. Samuel cares for two siblings.   

For five years, he has been selling soap, milk, and batteries in Thinkers Village Community on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 18,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 90,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cartons of soap, milk, and batteries for his business.  He describes himself as a very kind person. His goal is to improve his business and continue to educate his children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Dorithy is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more soap, milk, and batteries for his business.

loans.name: Vahagn

texts.en: Vahagn S. sells candies and sweets from a rented shop. Vahagn supports his pensioner mother. To meet customer demand and expand his business, Vahagn is planning to purchase more goods for his shop.

loans.use: To buy more goods for his shop

loans.name: Vanush

texts.en: Vanush M. is 55 years old. Together with his wife, he lives in Garnahovit village, Aragatsotn region, Armenia. Vanush works as a bus driver but his driver’s salary is very low and it is impossible to support his household with it. To have extra financial means, the couple is occupied in cattle breeding and land cultivation. To improve his household economy, Vanush is planning to buy more cattle.

loans.use: To buy more cattle

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is married with three children, all of whom are at school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She lives in and rents a house which has no electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, food and school fees.
Harriet has been in business buying and selling beans for the last four years. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living. She sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. Harriet plans to use this loan to buy more bags of beans. She buys bags of beans from the villages of Masaka and uses public transport to and from buying beans. She sells these beans in Nakulabye market and goes for shopping once a month. Her business challenges include transportation and seasonality. In the future, she hopes to own a delivery van. She decided to join Kiva partner, MCDT, because it is reliable.

loans.use: To buy more bags of beans

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Gondoun B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is Able. He is 33 years old, married and has four children who are between three months and 12 years old. He was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to lack of financial support. Gondoun cares for two siblings.   

For five years, he has been involved with the transportation (motorcycle) business in Thinkers Village Community on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 10,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 50,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more spare parts and petroleum for his motorcycle. He describes himself as a good and kind man. His dream is to grow his business and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts and petroleum for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Gulmira

texts.en:
Gulmira D. is 42 years old and has three children – one son aged 7 and two daughters aged 14 and 19 years, the youngest of which helps in the household. Gulmira’s husband went off to Russia in search of a living to support his family.
Gulmira is a respectable and diligent person. She graduated from State Medical College and worked in a hospital. Unfortunately, her salary as a nurse was very low and didn’t meet her children's expenses. Gulmira got a job as a seller at a local train station selling foodstuffs to passengers, and worked there for three years. In 2005, Gulmira decided to start up her own business. She earned her starting capital of 15,000 KGS from selling cattle, and with this capital she bought a parcel of clothes for resale. Her business started well and in 2007 she applied for a loan of 20,000 KGS to broaden her assortment of clothes. Gulmira used her loan as intended and repaid it without any delays. 
Gulmira proposes to use this loan of 70,000 KGS to purchase a seasonal assortment of clothes for adults and children. With the revenues from the loan, Gulmira plans to buy her own little shop.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: God Grace Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Grace.

She is 53 years old, married and has five children who range from 8 to 34 years old. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. For 13 years, she has been selling fufu (a kind of food produced from cassava) in Gbengba Town Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of cassava. She describes herself as a hard-working woman. Her dream is to grow her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cassava

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr:
Marie M.  est une femme de 50 ans, née à Butare, province du Sud du Rwanda. Elle est mariée et a quatre enfants, le moins âgée a  15 ans et le plus âgée  a 25 ans, tous ses 4 enfants sont allé à l’école.Marie et sa famille  habitent à Nyamata.

Son activité est le commerce des maniocs et farine de manioc dans laquelle on prépare le FUFU( pate de manioc) dans le petit marché de NYAMATA. Elle a une expérience de 7 ans dans ce domaine.
Le crédit contracté avec ACB est  le premier et va lui aider d’améliorer son business de commerce des maniocs et sa farine et à payer le minerval des ses enfants et le bien être de sa famille. Ses épargnes lui permet d’acheter deux vaches pour avoir du lait pour les enfants :
Dans l’avenir, elle compte devenir un gros commerçant des maniocs et sa farine, pourra contracter un nouveau prêt d’un gros montant pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaires, ainsi elle pourra acheter un champ pour augmenter l’étendu cultivé les maniocs et pourra fournir d’autres marchés comme Ruhuha.
texts.en:
Marie M., age 40, was born in Butare, a province in southern Rwanda. She's married and the mother of four children, aged three to ten. Out of them, three attended school. Emmanuel's family lives in Nyamata. Her business consists in selling cassava and tapioca, used to prepare FUFU (a staple food of Central Africa) at Nyamata's small market. She has seven years of experience in this field. The loan from ACB is her first, and will help her to improve her business selling manioc and manioc flour and pay tuition for her children. It also improved the well-being of her family. Her savings enable her to buy two cows to get milk for her children. In the future, she intends to become a large clothing reseller, and get a new sizable loan to increase her revenue. She will thus be able to buy a field to increase her cassava plantation, and supply other markets, such as the one in Ruhuha.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a lot to grow cassava

loans.name: Jean-Claude

texts.fr:
jeune homme âgé de 35ans, célibataire sans enfant, il est dans l'alimentation depuis novembre 2009 à la fin de ses études universitaires pour éviter le chômage.
ses recettes journalieres sont bonnes et peut vendre jusqu'à 45000f par jour.
Le prêt qu'il va recevoir  va le permettre d'achéter: 2 cartons de boites de lait en poudre,2 cartons de boites de sardines à l'huile,2cartons des spaghettis,2packs des jus en boite, 5packs d'eau minérale,2cartons des biscuits et 10 sachets des bonbons.
sa vision est de faire plus des bénéfices et de se lancer dans la construction immobiliere.Il pense iradiquer la pauvreté au niveau de sa famille , soutenir  ces  frères et soeurs qui sont encore sur le banc de l'école.
il est considéré très ouvert  et son handicap ne l' empêche pas de réussir.
texts.en:
Jean-Claude D., age 35, is single and without children. Since November 2009, after finishing his studies, he's been in the food business to avoid being unemployed. His daily revenue is good, and he can sell up to 45'000 F per day. The loan he's about to receive will enable him to buy 2 boxes of powdered milk, 2 boxes of cans of sardines in oil, 2 boxes of spaghetti, 2 packs of canned fruit juice, 5 packs of mineral water, 2 boxes of biscuits, and 10 packs of candies. He envisions to increase his profits and to go into real estate construction. He plans to eradicate poverty in his family, and support his brothers and sisters who are still attending school. He's regarded as very open and his disability doesn't prevent him from succeeding.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy powdered milk, sardines in oil, spaghetti, canned fruit juice, mineral water, biscuits, and candies

loans.name: Sun Kumari

texts.en:
This is 40 year-old Sun Kumari N.. She is married and has 5 children, four sons and one daughter. In 2007, she established her cow's milk sales business. Working 6 days a week and 6 hours a day, she supports her family.

She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW which she used to purchase a young milk giving cow. In the future Sun Kumari plans to grow the business. She thanks you for your support.

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk, from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a BPW loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

This loan was administered by BPW's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy a young milk-giving cow.

loans.name: Bhagabati

texts.en:
This is 40 year-old Bhagabati T.. She is married and has 10 children, three sons and seven daughters. In 2006, she established her agricultural farming business. Working 7 days a week and 6 hours a day, she supports her family.

She will use her loan to buys seeds and fertilizers for her work. In the future, Bhagabati plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a BPW loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase more seed and fertilizer and to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

This loan was administered by BPW's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Parmashwori

texts.en:
This is 42 year-old Parmashwori M.. She is married and has 2 children aged 19 and 17. In 2006, she established her agricultural farming business. Working 7 days a week and 6 hours a day, she supports her family.

She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buys seeds and fertilizers for her work. In the future, Parmashwori plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a BPW loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase more seed and fertilizer that allows them to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

This loan was administered by BPW's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ratna Keshari

texts.en:
This is 32 year-old Ratna keshari S.. She is married and has two children aged 19 and 17. In 2006, she established her small restaurant business. Working 7 days a week and 6 hours a day, she supoorts her family.

She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW which she used to buy cooking materials. In the future, Ratna keshari plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Whether on the streets of Kathmandu or in the villages outside of the capital, tea shops are places of business and meeting in Nepal. Called a chiya pasal, these tea shops make a sweet, milky tea that can be purchased for a few cents a cup. With a BPW loan, BPW's borrowers are able to keep their store shelves stocked while increasing their profit margins by buying in greater volume.

This loan was administered by BPW's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy food for her restaurant.

loans.name: Subita

texts.en:
Mrs. Subita L. lives in Chetrapati which is located in Kathmandu district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in small businesses like grocery stores, small hotels, and stationery stores.

Mrs. L. lives with her husband, who works in a government office, and two children. She has one son and one daughter: her daughter is studying in grade 5 and her son is in grade 4.

Mrs. L. is engaged in her own small restaurant which she opened four years ago. She sells different types of food items in her restaurant, especially Nepali food. She also serves tea and coffee.

Now, Mrs. L. is requesting an Rs 20,000 loan to purchase necessary food ingredients for her business.

loans.use: To buy cooking ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Shila

texts.en:
This is 45 year old Shila T.. She is married and has 2 children aged 17 and 14. In 2006, she established her cow's milk selling business. Working 7 days a week and 6 hours a day, she supports her family. In the future, Shila plans to improve the economic conditions of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a BPW loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.

This loan was administered by BPW's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

loans.use: To buy a young cow.

loans.name: Edma Clarisa

texts.es: Edma tiene 87 años, ella se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general, pues siempre está pendiente de lo que sus clientes solicitan, pues es una gran variedad de productos, ella tiene mucha experiencia en el negocio y en ser cliente de Fundación pues ha sido de mucha ayuda por lo que han sido para la inversión de su negocio. El financiamiento es para la compra de bolsos, calzado, sabanas, ropa interior y toallas. A pesar de su edad siempre está con todas las ganas de salir adelante pues tiene todo el entusiasmo de seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
Edma is 87 and makes a living selling general merchandise. She is always aware of what her customers request and it's a great variety of things. She has a lot of experience in the business as well as being a Fundacion customer. Fundacion has been of great help investing in her business. The loan is to buy, hand-bags, shoes, sheets, underwear and towels. Despite her age she still has the will to get ahead and work with great enthusiasm.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Merci Nayibe

texts.es:
Mercy P. es una joven que vive en la ciudad de Cartagena donde tiene su negocio llamado Variedades Estrella, Está solicitando un credikiva, que es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, para surtir su negocio con mercancía que en este momento se le está agotando y tiene alta rotación, como perfumes, bolsos para damas, calzado infantil, artículos de cacharrería y otros.
Su negoció nació con su sueño emprendedor de ser independiente mediante la oferta de productos que sus clientes necesitan y que a ella también le gusta vender. Por eso a futuro quiere convertirlo en una gran empresan que la ayude a aumentar siempre sus condiciones de vida y las de la familia de tres hijos que planea con su esposo hacia el futuro.
Su meta principal es tener varias unidades de comercialización en sitios altamente concurridos   y generar empleos mediante ellos. En la actualidad enfrenta el desafío de prepararse física y mentalmente, para empezar el sueño de tener su familia y ampliar su negocio, que en la actualidad se encuentra en una habitación de su vivienda y no es visible al público.
texts.en:
Mercy P. is a young woman who lives in the city of Cartagena, where she has a shop, called "Variedades Estrella". She is seeking a Kiva loan - her first loan with [field partner] Fundación Mario Santo Domingo - to stock her shop with additional merchandise. At the moment she has a high turn over and is running out of items such as perfumes, handbags, baby shoes, and crockery. Mercy's business was born of her dream to be independent. It has been able to grow because she offers the right goods for her customers, and because she enjoys selling. She would like it to become a big company in the future, which will help her improve her quality of life - and that of the three children she and her husband hope to have one day! Her goal is to have a chain of stores, in busy areas, and to employ people to work in them. Now she faces the challenge of preparing herself, physically and mentally, to realize her dream of having a family and growing her business, which at the moment is located in a room of their house and is not easily seen by passers-by.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To re-stock her business with goods she is running out of, such as perfumes, handbags, baby shoes and crockery

loans.name: Lorcy Del Carmen

texts.es:
Lorcy es una mujer que vive en la ciudad de Cartagena y se dedica a la actividad de comerciante en su negocio llamado "Comercializadora S.",  ella tiene 3 hijos en las edades de 25 a 28 años que ya estan graduados y ahora son trabajadores independientes. En la actualidad solicita un credikiva que es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para comprar nuevas líneas de productos como calzado, sudadera vestidos formales, perfumes entre otros.
Lorcy inició su negocio vendiendo productos por catálogos y de tratamientos adelgazantes  y de belleza  en general para;  esto debió capacitarse y conocer muy bien los productos y experimentar con ellos, lo mismo que le enseñaron la metodología de emprendimiento para viabilizar técnicamente las operaciones de su negocio  e identificar su  mercado y saber como abordarlo. 
Sueña con ser mayorista y con tener un local en un centro comercial donde abordar un cliente cautivo que forme parte de la dinámica misma de cada uno de estos establecimientos comerciales  y justamente de aquí se deriva su mayor desafío que es conseguir el capital  y los socios para emprender su sueño en optimas condiciones.
texts.en:
Lorcy is a woman who lives in the city of Cartagena and makes a living through her business named "Comercializadora S.." She has 3 children between the ages of 25 and 28 who have all graduated and have jobs. She is requesting a Kiva loan, which is her first with Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, to purchase some new product lines. These include: footwear, sweatshirts, formal dresses, perfumes and others. Lucy started this business selling diet and beauty products through catalogs. She had to train and familiarize herself with the products as well as try them herself. She also learned entrepreneurship to make her business viable as well as how to identify and target her market. She dreams of being a wholesaler with a place in a shopping mall where she can deal with a captive audience to add each location's business. One of her greatest challenges is finding partners and capital to live out this dream under ideal conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Add new product lines such as: footwear, sweatshirts, formal dresses, perfumes and others

loans.name: Los Triunfadores Del Rimac Group

texts.es:
Este grupo lo conforman nueve personas un varón y ocho mujeres todos ellos se esfuerzan día a día para salir adelante cada uno con su negocio. Prosperar es uno D. sus tantos objetivos que tienen tal es el caso D. Epifania quien es una mujer muy trabajadora, a raíz D. la separación que tuvo con su esposo empezó a trabajar vendiendo comida en una carreta cerca D. su casa, fue su suegra quien la motivó hacer esto, ella también es microempresaria.
Hace nueve años empezó a vender tunas (fruta D. la sierra) donD. se extrae D. la penca la cochinilla, parásito muy utilizado en dar color a prendas textiles. Esta fruta lo vendía D. casa en casa ofreciendo, iba además por los mercados. También trabajaba como empleada doméstica esto lo hacía desD. muy joven nos cuenta.
Con el primer crédito que recibió compró los insumos para hacer lo que tenía en mente cachangas, café, pollo frito; fue captando clientes con el tiempo es así que ha aumentado más en capital y actualmente por la buena sazón que tiene para sus comidas la contratan para cocinar en ciertos eventos como cumpleaños, aniversaR..
Este negocio le ha ido bien hasta el momento supo educar a sus hijos con el ingreso D. estas ventas, así mismo construyó su casa en el terreno que heredó D. sus padres fallecidos. Sus hijos son profesionales, tiene un último hijo D. 14 años quien aún estudia en la escuela. Necesita invertir en los insumos para seguir vendiendo anticuchos, pescado frito, cachangas, dado a que está cerca el aniversario D. país Perú y habrá muchos turistas por la zona.
texts.en:
This group is comprised of nine people, one man and eight women. All of them strive day to day to get ahead in their businesses. To prosper is one of the objectives that they have. That is the case with Epifania, a very hard-working woman. Upon separating from her husband she started to work selling food from a cart close to her house. It was her mother-in-law who urged her to do this. She is also a small businesswoman. Nine years ago she started selling prickly pears (fruit of the mountain range). She extracts the cochineal insect, a parasite that is often used to give color to clothing fabrics, from the pulpy part. She sold this fruit by going door to door and at the markets. She also worked as a domestic employee, which she says she has done since she was very young. With the first loan that she received she bought supplies to make “cachangas” (a type of bread maD. from wheat flour), coffee, and fried chicken. In time she was attracting customers. That is how she has increased her capital. Now, because of the good seasoning that her food has, she has been hired to cook for special events like birthdays and anniversaries. This business has gone well for her. With her income from these sales she knew to give her children an education. At the same time she built a house on land that she inherited from her deceased parents. Her children are professionals. Her last son is 14 years old, and he is still in school. She needs to invest in supplies to continue selling kebobs, fried fish, and cachangas. The anniversary of the country of Peru is near, and there will be lots of tourists in the area.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies: chicken, fish, and beef heart to make her kebobs

loans.name: Tereza De Jesus

texts.es:
Tereza es una mujer de 49 años de edad, trabajadora desde su juventud, para lograr la subsistencia de cada día. Vive junto con su familia, cuatro hijos y su esposo trabaja de conductor.
Hoy en día es docente y comerciante de productos de Avon desde hace varios años, 
Pues solo con su trabajo como maestra no da, ya que es bajo, es por eso nace la idea de comenzar a vender cosmético que en el mismo colegio ha hecho el ochenta por siento de sus clientes, el cual da al crédito de la quincena.
A través del apoyo de Afodenic con sus financiamientos ha logrado tener sus mejoras a su vivienda.
Pues a un falta mucho por hacer pero va poco a poco ya que hay que cubrir las necesidades alimenticias.
Con este crédito comprara mercadería de productos variados Avon como: perfumes de dama y caballero, cremas, pinturas de labios, vanidad, tonificador entre otros. Logrando invertir más, para aumentar las ventas y sus ganancias la cual ocupa para pagar gastos básicos de agua y luz.
texts.en:
Tereza is a 49-year-old woman who has worked hard since her youth to earn a living everyday. She lives with her family of four children and her husband, who works as a driver. She is a teacher and and has sold Avon products for several years since her teaching work alone is not enough because the pay is low. This is why she thought of starting to sell cosmetics. Eighty percent of her customers come from her school, and she gives them credit for two weeks. With Afodenic's financial support, she has managed to make improvements to her home. There is still a lot to do, but it goes little by little because she must also feed her family. With this loan Tereza will buy assorted Avon products like: ladies' and men's perfumes, creams, lipstick, cosmetic bags, toner, etc. She is managing to invest more in order to increase her sales and earnings, which concerns her because she must pay the water and light bills.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Avon products
